column10: title=Walt Disney's Mickey Mouse: The Ultimate History

column1: '''''Mr. Mouse Takes a Trip''''' is a 1940 American animated [[short film]] produced by [[Walt Disney Animation Studios
column2: Walt Disney Productions]] and released by [[RKO Pictures
column3: RKO Radio Pictures]]. The film was directed by [[Clyde Geronimi]] and features original music by [[Frank Churchill]] and [[Oliver Wallace]]. The film was animated by Clyde Geronimi, Ken Muse, Ed Love, Marvin Woodward, and Ray Abrams.<ref name=bcdb>\"[http://www.bcdb.com/cartoon/3965-Mr_Mouse_Takes_A_Trip.html Mr. Mouse Takes A Trip]\". ''www.bcdb.com''</ref> The voice cast includes [[Walt Disney]] as Mickey, Lee Millar as Pluto, and [[Billy Bletcher]] as Pete.<ref>{{cite book
column6: title=Disney Voice Actors: A Biographical Dictionary

column1: The cartoon follows [[Mickey Mouse]] and his dog [[Pluto (Disney)
column2: Pluto]] traveling by train, despite a rule forbidding dogs from entering the train; [[Pete (Disney)
column4: conductor]] intent on enforcing this rule.

column1: Leaving for vacation, Mickey Mouse and Pluto arrive at a train station in [[Burbank, California]] (home of [[Walt Disney Studios (Burbank)
column2: Walt Disney Productions headquarters]]). They board a west-bound train to [[Pomona (Amtrak station)
column3: Pomona]], but are both immediately kicked off by the conductor, played by Pete, stating that dogs aren't allowed (side gag reveals Pluto's luggage to contain bones).  Pete then rambles off the train's destinations and forces his watch to tell him when the train is ready to leave.  When the watch does show its time for the train to go, Pete calls \"All aboard!\"

column1: Mickey, at this point, decides to smuggle Pluto onboard by squeezing the dog inside his suitcase. At first, the handle breaks, making Mickey almost leave Pluto behind, but he recovers the suitcase and manages to make it aboard the caboose just as the train is leaving the platform. Later, Pluto barks, wanting to be let out.  Mickey reminds him that he will be thrown off if Pete finds out that Pluto's on the train, so he takes Pluto out and unsquashes him.  The freedom is only short lived, however, as Pete is coming through the train to collect tickets, forcing Mickey to squash Pluto back into position in the suitcase. After biting \"OK\" in Mickey's tickets, Pete sees Mickey's suitcase containing Pluto in the seat and forcefully throws it into an overhead baggage net. This causes Pluto to bark, making Pete suspicious.

He then recognizes Mickey, who tries to hide behind a large newspaper and make it look like the barking was coming from him. Realizing that Pluto has been stowed in the suitcase, Pete menacingly asks Mickey if he is alone, which Mickey states that he is alone, Pete then makes up a story about owning a little cat who'd cry when he was all alone and screams a loud \"MEOW!\" (even making his face closely resemble a real cat) at the suitcase causing Pluto to leap out barking at the \"cat\". Realizing his cover's been blown, Pluto ducks back into the suitcase, but Pete has already figured it out.  Before he can catch the pair, Mickey and Pluto run away and a chase ensues on board the train.

Mickey and Pluto first hide in a sleeping car where Pete mistakenly intrudes on a female passenger and gets assaulted. Pete then stumbles into another bed where Mickey and Pluto (disguised as babies) are hiding. Pete apologizes for the intrusion, but quickly finds out after covering up Pluto's tail.  Just as Mickey and Pluto think that they fooled Pete, Pete bursts in and threatens to beat them to a pulp, but sudden darkness from the train running through a tunnel allows the pair to escape, leaving Pete to beat the mattress to a pulp and experience a brief entanglement with the springs.

Mickey and Pluto masquerade as the conductor by hiding in Pete's own coat and hat which they'd had taken off in the tunnel. After getting false directions from Mickey with a deep voice, Pete catches on and threatens to catch them, but ends up disturbing the female passenger again.  Pete receives another beating and, unintentionally taking the passenger's hat, gets pricked by one of her needles.  Mickey disguises himself as an [[Stereotypes of Native Americans
column2: Indian chief]] with Pluto in his [[papoose]], but Pete sees through their disguise after Pluto bites his hand.

column1: While Mickey and Pluto are next to an open window, Pluto is caught on a passing [[mail hook]] which whisks him outside the train. Mickey runs after him through the train, and is just able to grab Pluto as he exits the caboose. Pete throws their luggage out after them and they fall to the ground from the mail hook. Mickey then looks up at the station sign and is pleasantly surprised that they have arrived at Pomona.

column4: [[Walt Disney]] (left) and [[Billy Bletcher]] recording voice-overs for ''Mr. Mouse Takes a Trip'']]

column1: ''Mr. Mouse Takes a Trip'' is unique among Disney shorts in that film footage exists of the [[voice-over]] session, which included Walt Disney and Billy Bletcher. According to film historian [[Leonard Maltin]], the footage was not known to exist and only discovered (as of 2004) \"not too many years ago.\"<ref>Quoted from \"Walt Disney Treasures: Mickey Mouse in Living Color, Volume Two,\" disc 1</ref>

The black-and-white film, which is about ten minutes in length, is the only known footage of Disney performing as Mickey Mouse. It was included as an extra on the 1997 VHS and 2000 DVD of ''[[Fun and Fancy Free]]'', and on the 2004 DVD release \"[[Walt Disney Treasures: Wave Three#Mickey Mouse in Living Color, Volume Two
column2: Walt Disney Treasures: Mickey Mouse in Living Color, Volume Two]]\" as an [[Easter egg (media)
column3: easter egg]].<ref>The easter egg is accessed from the main menu by clicking on Mickey's cane.</ref>

column1: In September 1940, a one-page adaptation of ''Mr. Mouse Takes a Trip'' appeared in ''[[Good Housekeeping]]'' magazine. In this version Pete discovers Pluto by seeing his tail sticking out of the suitcase. Instead of being kicked off the train, Mickey and Pluto are confined to the baggage car. The story was told in [[Verse (poetry)
column2: verse]] and was illustrated by Tom Wood.<ref>{{cite book
title         = Walt Disney's Mickey and the Gang: Classic Stories in Verse

column1: }}</ref><ref>[http://coa.inducks.org/story.php?c=W+GH+4009-%3F1 Mr. Mouse Takes a Trip] at [[INDUCKS]]</ref>

In October 1940, a prose version of ''Mr. Mouse Takes a Trip'' was printed in the first edition of ''[[Walt Disney Comics and Stories]]''. This five-page version is a closer retelling of the film, with the added detail that Mickey is heading to an \"important meeting\" in Pomona which he can't be late for. Pluto comes along only because he would get lonely if he stayed home alone.

In 2010, the film inspired the Italian comic story \"Topolino, Pluto e la gita in montagna,\" or \"Mickey, Pluto, and the Trip to the Mountain.\" The story, published in the May edition of ''Extralarge XL Disney'', is 25 pages and written and illustrated by Enrico Faccini<ref>[http://coa.inducks.org/story.php?c=I+PD+++47-1 Topolino, Pluto e la gita in montagna] at INDUCKS</ref>
*c. 1965 – Highlights included in \"Mickey's Memorable Moments, Volume 2\" ([[Super 8 mm film

column2: The Ink and Paint Club]]'', episode # 1.43: \"On Vacation\" (TV)

column1: *2004 – \"[[Walt Disney Treasures: Wave Three#Mickey Mouse in Living Color, Volume Two
column2: Walt Disney Treasures: Mickey Mouse in Living Color, Volume Two]]\" (DVD)
Walt Disney's Funny Factory: With Mickey]]\" (DVD)

column1: *2009 – \"Walt Disney Animation Collection: Classic Short Films Volume 1: Mickey and the Beanstalk\" (DVD)

'''Grégory Villemin''' (24 August 1980 – 16 October 1984) was a French boy from [[Lépanges-sur-Vologne]] who was murdered at the age of 4. His body was found four kilometers (2.5 miles) away in the [[Vologne]] River near [[Docelles]]. The case became known as the '''Grégory Affair''' ({{lang-fr
column2: l'Affaire Grégory}}) and for decades has received widespread media coverage in France, where it continues to capture the public interest.<ref name=NYT>{{cite news
column4: title=All of France is asking: Who killed petit Gregory?
column7: accessdate=31 January 2017}}</ref> The murder remains unsolved.<ref name=Local>{{cite news
column11: title=Gregory: The smiling boy whose murder haunts France 33 years on

column1: From September 1981 to October 1984, Grégory's parents, Jean-Marie and Christine Villemin, and Jean-Marie's parents, Albert and Monique Villemin, received numerous anonymous letters and phone calls from a man threatening revenge against Jean-Marie for some unknown offense.<ref name=\"Hayden\">{{cite news
column5: title=Who Killed Little Grégory? Netflix's new true crime doc is a tragic, chaotic story of murder
column12: title=Affaire Grégory : ce que déversait le corbeau

column1: Shortly after 5:00 pm on 16 October 1984, Christine Villemin reported Grégory to police as missing after she noticed he was no longer playing in the Villemins' front yard.<ref name=\"Hayden\"/> At 5:30 pm, Gregory's uncle Michel Villemin informed the family he had just been told by an anonymous caller that the boy had been taken and thrown into the [[Vologne
column6: title=Affaire Gregory : mort de Michel Villemin
column9: location=Nancy, France}}</ref> At 9:00 pm, Grégory's body was found in the Vologne with his hands and feet bound with rope and a woollen hat pulled down over his face.<ref name=Local/><ref name=LATimes/>

column3: The [[Vologne]], where Grégory Villemin's body was discovered]]

column1: On 17 October the Villemins received an anonymous letter that said \"I have taken vengeance\".<ref name=NYT/> From then on, the unidentified author, whose written and telephone communications since 1981 indicated he possessed detailed knowledge of the extended Villemin family, was referred to in the media as ''Le Corbeau'' \"the Crow\", French slang for an anonymous letter-writer, a term made popular by the 1943 film ''[[Le Corbeau]]''.<ref name=NYT/><ref name=LATimes>{{cite news

Bernard Laroche, a cousin of Jean-Marie Villemin, was implicated in the murder by handwriting experts and by a statement from Laroche's sister-in-law Murielle Bolle, and taken into custody on 5 November 1984.<ref name=\"Levin\">{{cite magazine
column5: title=A Little Boy's Murder and His Father's 'revenge' Leave a Quiet French Valley in Turmoil
column9: location=New York, NY}}</ref> Bolle later recanted her testimony, saying it had been coerced by police.<ref name=\"Levin\"/> Laroche, who denied any part in the crime or being \"the Crow\", was released from custody on 4 February 1985.<ref name=\"Levin\"/> Jean-Marie Villemin vowed in front of the press that he would kill Laroche.<ref name=Local/> On 25 March handwriting experts identified Grégory's mother Christine as the likely author of the anonymous letters.<ref name=NYT/> On 29 March 1985, Jean-Marie Villemin shot and killed Laroche as he was leaving for work.<ref name=\"Levin\"/> He was convicted of murder and sentenced to 5 years in prison.<ref name=Local/>  With credit for time served awaiting trial and a partial suspension of the sentence, he was released in December 1987 after having served two and a half years.<ref>{{cite news
column14: location=Nancy, France}}</ref> In July 1985, Christine Villemin was charged with the murder.<ref>{{cite news
column18: title=The murder of little Grégory: unsolved case that haunted France may soon yield secrets
column21: location=London, United Kingdom}}</ref>  Pregnant at the time, she launched a hunger strike that lasted 11 days.<ref name=\"Cawley\">{{cite news
column25: title=French Media Stretch Boundaries of Murder Mystery
column28: location=Chicago, IL}}</ref> She was freed after an appeals court cited flimsy evidence and the absence of a coherent motive.<ref name=\"Cawley\"/> Christine Villemin was cleared of the charges on 2 February 1993.<ref>{{cite news
column30: title=Mother cleared in 'little Gregory' murder case

column1: The case was reopened in 2000 to allow for DNA testing on a stamp used to send one of the anonymous letters, but the tests were inconclusive.<ref name=France24>{{cite news
column3: title=Judge reopens case of four-year-old Gregory, murdered in 1984
column6: accessdate=31 January 2017}}</ref> In December 2008, following an application by the Villemins, a judge ordered the case reopened to allow DNA testing of the rope used to bind Grégory, the letters, and other evidence.<ref name=France24/> This testing proved inconclusive.<ref name=France24/> Further DNA testing in April 2013 on Grégory's clothes and shoes was also inconclusive.<ref name=Local/>

column1: On 14 June 2017, based on new evidence, three people were arrested—Grégory's great-aunt and great-uncle, as well as an aunt—the widow of Michel, who died in 2010.<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=Gregory Villemin child murder: Three held in 1984 French mystery
column9: access-date= }}</ref> The aunt was released, while the great-aunt and great-uncle invoked their right to remain silent.<ref>{{cite news
column14: title=Affaire Grégory : «plusieurs personnes ont concouru» au crime
column19: language=fr-FR}}</ref>  Muriel Bolle was also arrested and she was held for 36 days before being released, as were the others who had been detained.<ref name=\"Teller\">{{cite news
column23: title=Grégory case: Ex-investigator denounces \"lies\" in Murielle Bolle's book
column25: work=Teller Report}}</ref> On 11 July 2017, the magistrate in charge of the first investigation, Jean-Michel Lambert, committed suicide, citing in a farewell letter to a local newspaper the increasing pressure resulting from the reopening of the case.<ref>{{cite web
column27: title=Affaire Grégory : l'ancien juge Jean-Michel Lambert retrouvé mort

column1: In 2018, Murielle Bolle authored a book on her involvement in the case, ''Breaking the Silence''.<ref name=\"Teller\"/> In the book, Bolle maintained her innocence and that of Bernard Laroche, and blamed police for coercing her into implicating him.<ref name=\"Teller\"/> In June 2017, Bolle's cousin Patrick Faivre told police that Bolle's family had physically abused her in 1984 in order to make her recant her initial testimony against Bernard Laroche.<ref name=\"Teller2\">{{cite news
column5: work=Teller Report}}</ref> In her book, Bolle accused Faivre of lying about the reason why she recanted her initial statement.<ref name=\"Teller2\"/> In June 2019, she was indicted for aggravated defamation after Faivre lodged a complaint with police.<ref name=\"Teller2\"/>

column2: alias = Richard Beynon, King Richard, Ratchet Richard
label             =[[Ultra Music]], [[Atlantic Records]], [[Armada Music]], [[Sony Music Entertainment]],[[Revealed Recordings]], [[Spinnin Records

column1: '''Richard Glenmor Beynon''', professionally known by his [[stage name]] '''BYNON''',<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web

The [[clarinet]] prodigy turned DJ/Producer/Songwriter comes from a family of musicians hailing from [[South Wales]] (U.K.). He grew up in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]]. He studied at [[Langley Fine Arts School]], [[Juilliard School]] ,and [[McGill University]].

column2: bass]], keyboards, [[piano]] and [[drums]] before becoming a clarinet player. He performed with the Surrey Youth Orchestra, the Vancouver Summer Pops Youth Orchestra and won gold at the Kiwanis International Fraser Valley Music Festival.

column1: Collaborating with his father, BYNON arranged and produced three successful albums featuring many genres of music including classical, jazz and pop.<ref name=\":0\" />

A seasoned performer, BYNON toured around North America, with multiple dates in Europe and Asia. Highlights include Paradiso Festival at the Gorge in Seattle, a four year residency in the Las Vegas circuit featuring Legendary Pool Party REHAB and SLS, and most recently in 2018 at îleSoniq Festival, in his adopted home town of Montreal.

With his freshman releases alongside Dannic, Project 46 & Feenixpawl, his name popped up monthly on [[Beatport]] top 10 charts, (Golden Hearts, Eyes, Home) on Revealed, Ultra Records and Atlantic throughout 2014.
At the end of 2015 BYNON's massive rework Ganja Man featuring Sean Paul went viral on Youtube, accumulating over 23 Million Views.
In early 2016, BYNON decided to focus primarily on songwriting and production, working with [[Sean Paul]], [[Kaskade]], [[Ilsey Juber
column3: Mako]], Jane XØ and many more. He has been involved with major projects at Columbia, Atlantic, Sony and Warner Music. [[Corey Hart (singer)
column4: Corey Hart]] commissioned him to co-write and produce Jonathan Roy's sophomore album ''Mr. Optimist Blues,'' which included the Certified Gold Record Smash \"Daniella Denmark\".

column1: He has co-written numerous #1 itunes albums and singles, and issued several solo releases and remixes in 2018.
BYNON resides in both [[Montreal]] and [[Los Angeles]].

column2: caption          = Traditional Ukrainian Paska bread with a [[pysanka]] and [[willow]] switches
country          = European / Eurasian countries with predominant Orthodox religion

column10: title=T-Bone Whacks and Caviar Snacks: Cooking with Two Texans in Siberia and the Russian Far East
column22: access-date=2019-03-02}}</ref> Easter bread tradition and particularly spread in countries with predominant [[Eastern Orthodox Church
column23: Eastern Orthodox]] religion or cultural connections to the ancient [[Byzantine Empire]].<ref>{{Cite web
column25: title=Orthodox traditions observed locally for Easter season
column30: access-date=2018-11-19}}</ref> Paska breads are a traditional element in the easter holidays of Ukraine, Russia, Turkey, Iran, Belarus, Armenia, Romania, Moldova, Georgia and parts of Bulgaria as well as the [[Assyrian–Chaldean–Syriac diaspora]]. Due to its geographical closeness, it is also widespread in Slovakia. Meanwhile it is also eaten in countries with immigrant populations from Eastern Europe such as the United States, Canada and the United Kingdom.

column1: Easter is called in the Ukrainian language ''па́ска'' (''páska''/''Paska'') whilst in Russian it is spelt пасха (''paskha'')<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=T-Bone Whacks and Caviar Snacks: Cooking with Two Texans in Siberia
column12: access-date=}}</ref>. The Ukrainian word ''па́ска'' is traditionally used to describe the easter bread in Ukraine whilst Великден (''Velykden)'' is used to denote the day<ref>{{Cite web
column32: access-date=}}</ref>. Whilst Russia has its own easterbread called куліч (kulich) and the word пасха (paskha) is used to denote the day. The word is connected to ancient Greek word ''πάσκα'' (''páska'') and Georgian: ''პასკა'' (''Easter''), derived from the Orthodox believers in Byzantine Empire. The name is connected to the Jewish holiday of ''Pesach.''<ref>{{Cite book
column33: title=Silentium : and other reflections on memory, sorrow, place, and the sacred

column1: In Finland the name ''Pääsiäisleipä'' (\"Easter bread\") is used, because ''paska'' is an obscenity in Finnish meaning \"shit\".

column2: eggs]], [[flour]], and [[sugar]], except in Romania, where the recipe most commonly includes sweet cream, [[cottage cheese]], and/or [[sour cream]] along with [[Egg (food)
column3: eggs]], [[sugar]], [[raisins]], and [[rum]]. An egg and water mixture is used as a glaze.
Traditional Ukrainian Easter, Painting by Mykola Pymonenko ]]
Easter in modern day Ukraine Galicia (Halychyna)]]

column1: In Ukraine it is tradition to fill your easter basket (koshyk) with easter eggs (pysanky), easter bread (paska), sausage (kovbasa), butter, salt and other ceremonial foods on Easter Saturday. On Easter morning, after the liturgy and the blessing of the paska and other staples, everyone returns home to feast on the eggs, cold meats, and other goods that were blessed at church. <ref>{{Cite web
column11: access-date=}}</ref> After the matins all the people in the congregation exchange Easter greetings, give each other ''krashanky'', and then hurry home with their baskets of blessed food (''sviachene''). In eastern Ukraine they go home, place the ''sviachene'' on the table, and the oldest member of the family opens the cloths in which the food is wrapped, slices pieces from each item, and distributes them to members of the family along with a piece of unleavened bread that has also been blessed. In Western Ukraine, especially in the Hutsul region, the people first walk around the house three times, go to the stable, extend Easter greetings to the cattle, touch them with the ''sviachene'', scatter pieces of Easter bread and salt in the manger, and send holiday greetings to the bees. Only then do they enter the house, ceremoniously open the bundle (''dorinnyk'') over the heads of the children, and sit down to the table to break their fast.<ref>{{Cite web
column21: access-date=}}</ref> Modern pasky usually have a white glaze made from sugar and egg and are decorated on top with coloured wheat grains or poppy seeds. However, an old custom, which is still practised in some Ukrainian regions and diasporas, is to create dough ornaments for the paska. The symbolism of these ornaments is connected with spring themes: the awakening of nature, resurrection and rebirth. Birds, especially larks, as heralds of spring, took a much-deserved place on pasky.<ref>{{Cite web
column23: title=Tradition of Paska – Ukrainian Easter Bread

column1: The Christian faithful in many [[Eastern Christianity
column2: Eastern Christian]] countries eat this bread during Easter. Christian symbolism is associated with features of paska type breads. The inside of paska can be a swirl of yellow and white that is said to represent the [[resurrection of Jesus]] while the white represents the [[Holy Spirit]]. Other versions include chocolate, rice, or even savoury mixtures based on cheese. A version is made with maraschino cherries added to symbolize royal jewels in honor of the resurrection of Jesus.<ref>Joan Halmo [https://books.google.com/books?id=wOJ4sLwVllEC&pg=PA43&dq=Paska+bread&lr=#PPA43,M1 ''Celebrating the church year with young children''] Liturgical Press, 1988 {{ISBN

column1: Paska is eaten with \"hrudka\", also called ''syrek'', a bland sweet custard similar to cheese made from separated eggs and milk and beets mixed with [[horseradish]] (''chren''/''hrin'') and [[kielbasa]] (in Polish) or ''kovbasa'' (in Ukrainian).

In Iran and the diaspora, Assyrians will eat a Paska cake on Easter, ''Ida Gura''. The tall cake is decorated with a cross on top to represent [[Calvary]], the place of Jesus' crucifixion, and surrounded with colored eggs to symbolize the people who visited Jesus during his death and were at his cross.{{cn

'''''Pască''''' is a traditional Romanian and Moldovan pastry.<ref>[https://dexonline.ro/definitie/Pasc%C4%83 definition of pască (in Romanian)] dexonline.ro</ref> Pască is composed with eggs, sour cream, fresh cheese like [[urdă]], [[raisin]]s and sugar, and is especially made for [[Easter]]. The word ''Pască'' come from [[Latin]], ''[[wiktionary:Pascha
column5: title=A Portrait of an Assyrian Family in Iran

column1: * [[Paskha]], Russian Easter dish made from [[Quark (dairy product)
* [[Kozunak]] is the Bulgarian name for this type of Easter Bread

column1: Thums Up is a brand of [[cola]] in [[Indian beverages
column2: India]]. The logo is a red [[Thumbs signal
column3: thumbs up]]. It was introduced in 1977 to offset the withdrawal of [[The Coca-Cola Company]] from India. The brand was later bought by [[Coca-Cola]] who re-launched it in order to compete against [[Pepsi]].

column2: February 2012}}, Thums Up was the leader in the cola segment in India, commanding approximately 42% [[market share]] and an overall 15% market share in the Indian aerated waters market.<ref name=etf12>{{cite news
column3: title=Will Coke's 200ml pack price cut cannibalise Thums Up?

column1: Thums Up was created in 1977, after the American company Coca-Cola withdrew from India, due to regulations requiring it to disclose its formula<ref>{{Cite web
column6: access-date=2018-09-17}}</ref> and sell 60% of its equity to an Indian company under a government plan for foreign-owned companies to share stakes with domestic partners.<ref>{{cite book
column14: title=A Look Back at Coke’s Dramatic Return to India, 20 Years Later
column17: language=en-US}}</ref> The Chauhan brothers owned part of the [[Parle Agro
column18: Parle]] company and already had two other brands of soda, [[Limca]] and [[Gold Spot]], which were popular in India at the time. Thums Up quickly became the most popular and achieved a near [[monopoly]] among cola products in India during the 1980s, such as [[Campa Cola]], [[Double Seven (soft drink)
column19: Double Seven]], Dukes and [[United Breweries Group]]'s McDowell's Crush.

column1: Ramesh Chauhan had developed the formula from scratch, experimenting with ingredients such as cinnamon, cardamom, and nutmeg. The company also wanted the drink to be fizzy, even when it was not ice-cold, so it could be sold by vendors. After much testing and experimentation, the Chauhan brothers and their research team created a cola that was fizzier and spicier than Coca-Cola. They originally planned to name the drink “Thumbs Up,” but removed the “b” to make the name unique.<ref>[https://daily.social/story-of-thums-up/]{{dead link

column3: opened the market]] to multinationals, [[Pepsi]] was the first to come in. Thums Up and Pepsi subsequently engaged in heavy competition for endorsements. [[Pepsi]] spokespersons included major Indian movie stars like [[Juhi Chawla]], while Thums Up increased its spending on cricket sponsorship. Thums Up also introduced a larger {{Convert
column7: abbr=on}} bottle, branded \"MahaCola\" (meaning 'great [in size] cola'; the original size was {{Convert
column11: abbr=on}}). This nickname gained popularity in smaller towns where people would ask for \"Maha Cola\" instead of Thums Up.<ref>{{cite web
column13: title=A Big 'Thums Up' to India's Beloved Cola: A Brief History and Recipe

column1: In 1993, Coca-Cola re-entered the market and the three companies competed intensely. Later in the year, Coca-Cola bought the Parle owned drinks Gold Spot,Limca and Thums Up for $60 million. When this were sold to Coca-Cola, Thums Up had a [[market share]] of 85 percent in India.<ref name=etf12/>

Despite its strong overall equity, the brand was losing its popularity among the core cola-drinking age group of 12- to 25-year-olds, partly due to a lack of advertising. At first, Coca-Cola cut advertising and production for Thums Up to drive customers to their flagship brand,<ref name=\"outlookbiz\">{{cite news
column7: url=http://www.outlookbusiness.com/article_v3.aspx?artid=286425}}</ref> but soon realised that Thums Up customers would turn to Pepsi instead of Coke, were Thums Up withdrawn from the market. Instead, Coke decided to use Thums Up as a rival brand to Pepsi. The Coca-Cola Company by this time had about 60.5% share of the Indian soft-drink market but found out that if it took out Thums Up, it would remain with only 28.7% of the market (according to a report by NGO Finance & Trade in India), hence Thums Up was re-launched, targeting 30- to 40-year-olds.

column1: The brand was re-positioned as a \"manly\" drink, drawing on its strong taste qualities.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=The brand that refused to die

column1: Thums Up started an advertising campaign directly attacking Pepsi’s [[television advertisement
column2: television commercials]], focusing on the strength of the drink hoping that the depiction of an \"adult\" drink would appeal to young consumers. \"Grow up to Thums Up\" was a successful campaign. The brand's market share and equity increased.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=How Thums Up became the ruling cola of India.

column1: Today, the beverage is the leading cola in India, with 42 percent of the cola market share and 15 percent of the market share for all carbonated drinks. It is especially popular among teenagers, young adults, and people in their 30s and 40s.

According to Coca-Cola's Indian website, Thums Up contains: [[carbonated water]], [[sugar]], acidity regulator ([[E338]]), [[caffeine]], natural colour (150d) and added flavours (\"natural, nature identical and artificial flavouring substances\").<ref name=\"Coke India site\">{{cite web

column3: A can and glass of Thums Up]]

column1: The original Thums Up logo was a red [[thumbs up]] hand gesture with a slanted, white, sans-serif typeface. This would later be modified by Coca-Cola with blue strokes and a more modern-looking typeface.

The famous slogan until the early 1980s was \"Happy days are here again\", coined by [[copywriter]], [[Vasant Kumar]].  The slogan later became \"I want My Thunder\", and subsequently \"Taste the thunder!\"
Product placement in films was used in the 1980s with Thums Up appearing in the background of many Hindi films.<ref name=\"outlookbiz\"/>
Advertising campaigns from Thums Up build on its \"strength\" and its perception as a [[macho]] drink.<ref>{{cite web
In February 2012, popular South Indian actor [[Mahesh Babu]] became a spokesperson for Thums Up.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Mahesh Babu is national brand ambassador for Thums Up!

column1: In October 2012, Coca-Cola India signed [[Salman Khan]] once again as the brand ambassador of Thums Up. The company has also tied with Salman Khan's movie ''[[Dabangg 2]]'' and his charitable organisation as part of the deal.
Thums Up was a major sponsor of [[cricket]] matches and also had a notable presence at the [[Sharjah (emirate)
column2: Sharjah]] cricket matches. In the early 1980s, it came out with several [[postcard]]s featuring [[Sunil Gavaskar]] and [[Imran Khan]].

column1: Besides cricket, Parle’s southern bottler was a major sponsor of Indian [[motorsport]] in the 1980s. In addition to sponsoring several Indian track drivers in Sholavaram races, they sponsored several regional car and bike rallies. They were also associated for several seasons with the Lakshmi Mills [[Super Speeds]] team.
Post 1990s, Thums Up's celebrity endorsers were [[Chiranjeevi]], [[Mahesh Babu]], [[Vishal (actor)
column2: Vishal]],  [[Salman Khan]], [[Akshay Kumar]] and [[Ranveer Singh]].<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=How Thums Up became the ruling cola of India
column9: title=Coca-Cola India hikes Thums Up ad spend, signs on Chiranjeevi

column1: According to the [[The Brand Trust Report
column2: Brand Trust Report]] 2012 published by Trust Research Advisory, a brand analytics company, Thums Up was not positioned 140th among India's most trusted brands. Subsequently, in [[The Brand Trust Report
column3: Brand Trust Report]] 2013, Thums Up was ranked 170th among the most trusted brands in India while according to the [[The Brand Trust Report
column4: Brand Trust Report]] 2014, Thums Up was elevated to the 66th position among India's most trusted brands.<ref>{{Cite web

column2: Marathi]]), because it has a natural top like the \"Thums Up\" logo and is a popular sight from trains.

column1: Thums Up is a brand of [[cola]] in [[Indian beverages
column2: India]]. The logo is a red [[Thumbs signal
column3: thumbs up]]. It was introduced in 1977 to offset the withdrawal of [[The Coca-Cola Company]] from India. The brand was later bought by [[Coca-Cola]] who re-launched it in order to compete against [[Pepsi]].

column2: February 2012}}, Thums Up was the leader in the cola segment in India, commanding approximately 42% [[market share]] and an overall 15% market share in the Indian aerated waters market.<ref name=etf12>{{cite news
column3: title=Will Coke's 200ml pack price cut cannibalise Thums Up?

column1: Thums Up was created in 1977, after the American company Coca-Cola withdrew from India, due to regulations requiring it to disclose its formula<ref>{{Cite web
column6: access-date=2018-09-17}}</ref> and sell 60% of its equity to an Indian company under a government plan for foreign-owned companies to share stakes with domestic partners.<ref>{{cite book
column14: title=A Look Back at Coke’s Dramatic Return to India, 20 Years Later
column17: language=en-US}}</ref> The Chauhan brothers owned part of the [[Parle Agro
column18: Parle]] company and already had two other brands of soda, [[Limca]] and [[Gold Spot]], which were popular in India at the time. Thums Up quickly became the most popular and achieved a near [[monopoly]] among cola products in India during the 1980s, such as [[Campa Cola]], [[Double Seven (soft drink)
column19: Double Seven]], Dukes and [[United Breweries Group]]'s McDowell's Crush.

column1: Ramesh had developed the formula from scratch, experimenting with ingredients such as cinnamon, cardamom, and nutmeg. The company also wanted the drink to be fizzy, even when it was not ice-cold, so it could be sold by vendors. After much testing and experimentation, the Chauhan brothers and their research team created a cola that was fizzier and spicier than Coca-Cola. They originally planned to name the drink “Thumbs Up,” but removed the “b” to make the name unique.<ref>[https://daily.social/story-of-thums-up/]{{dead link

column3: opened the market]] to multinationals, [[Pepsi]] was the first to come in. Thums Up and Pepsi subsequently engaged in heavy competition for endorsements. [[Pepsi]] spokespersons included major Indian movie stars like [[Juhi Chawla]], while Thums Up increased its spending on cricket sponsorship. Thums Up also introduced a larger {{Convert
column7: abbr=on}} bottle, branded \"MahaCola\" (meaning 'great [in size] cola'; the original size was {{Convert
column11: abbr=on}}). This nickname gained popularity in smaller towns where people would ask for \"Maha Cola\" instead of Thums Up.<ref>{{cite web
column13: title=A Big 'Thums Up' to India's Beloved Cola: A Brief History and Recipe

column1: In 1993, Coca-Cola re-entered the market and the three companies competed intensely. Later in the year, Coca-Cola bought the Parle owned drinks Gold Spot,Limca and Thums Up for $60 million. When this were sold to Coca-Cola, Thums Up had a [[market share]] of 85 percent in India.<ref name=etf12/>

Despite its strong overall equity, the brand was losing its popularity among the core cola-drinking age group of 12- to 25-year-olds, partly due to a lack of advertising. At first, Coca-Cola cut advertising and production for Thums Up to drive customers to their flagship brand,<ref name=\"outlookbiz\">{{cite news
column7: url=http://www.outlookbusiness.com/article_v3.aspx?artid=286425}}</ref> but soon realised that Thums Up customers would turn to Pepsi instead of Coke, were Thums Up withdrawn from the market. Instead, Coke decided to use Thums Up as a rival brand to Pepsi. The Coca-Cola Company by this time had about 60.5% share of the Indian soft-drink market but found out that if it took out Thums Up, it would remain with only 28.7% of the market (according to a report by NGO Finance & Trade in India), hence Thums Up was re-launched, targeting 30- to 40-year-olds.

column1: The brand was re-positioned as a \"manly\" drink, drawing on its strong taste qualities.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=The brand that refused to die

column1: Thums Up started an advertising campaign directly attacking Pepsi’s [[television advertisement
column2: television commercials]], focusing on the strength of the drink hoping that the depiction of an \"adult\" drink would appeal to young consumers. \"Grow up to Thums Up\" was a successful campaign. The brand's market share and equity increased.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=How Thums Up became the ruling cola of India.

column1: Today, the beverage is the leading cola in India, with 42 percent of the cola market share and 15 percent of the market share for all carbonated drinks. It is especially popular among teenagers, young adults, and people in their 30s and 40s.

According to Coca-Cola's Indian website, Thums Up contains: [[carbonated water]], [[sugar]], acidity regulator ([[E338]]), [[caffeine]], natural colour (150d) and added flavours (\"natural, nature identical and artificial flavouring substances\").<ref name=\"Coke India site\">{{cite web

column3: A can and glass of Thums Up]]

column1: The original Thums Up logo was a red [[thumbs up]] hand gesture with a slanted, white, sans-serif typeface. This would later be modified by Coca-Cola with blue strokes and a more modern-looking typeface.

The famous slogan until the early 1980s was \"Happy days are here again\", coined by [[copywriter]], [[Vasant Kumar]].  The slogan later became \"I want My Thunder\", and subsequently \"Taste the thunder!\"
Product placement in films was used in the 1980s with Thums Up appearing in the background of many Hindi films.<ref name=\"outlookbiz\"/>
Advertising campaigns from Thums Up build on its \"strength\" and its perception as a [[macho]] drink.<ref>{{cite web
In February 2012, popular South Indian actor [[Mahesh Babu]] became a spokesperson for Thums Up.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Mahesh Babu is national brand ambassador for Thums Up!

column1: In October 2012, Coca-Cola India signed [[Salman Khan]] once again as the brand ambassador of Thums Up. The company has also tied with Salman Khan's movie ''[[Dabangg 2]]'' and his charitable organisation as part of the deal.
Thums Up was a major sponsor of [[cricket]] matches and also had a notable presence at the [[Sharjah (emirate)
column2: Sharjah]] cricket matches. In the early 1980s, it came out with several [[postcard]]s featuring [[Sunil Gavaskar]] and [[Imran Khan]].

column1: Besides cricket, Parle’s southern bottler was a major sponsor of Indian [[motorsport]] in the 1980s. In addition to sponsoring several Indian track drivers in Sholavaram races, they sponsored several regional car and bike rallies. They were also associated for several seasons with the Lakshmi Mills [[Super Speeds]] team.
Post 1990s, Thums Up's celebrity endorsers were [[Chiranjeevi]], [[Mahesh Babu]], [[Vishal (actor)

column2: producer     = A Kid Called Roots, [[Canibus]], [[Clark Kent (producer)
column3: Clark Kent]], [[Jerry 'Wonda' Duplessis]], Joe Servilus, LG, [[Salaam Remi]], [[Wyclef Jean]]

column1: '''''Can-I-Bus''''' is the debut album by [[rapper]] [[Canibus]], released on September 8, 1998 through [[Universal Records]]. The album was released after the rapper's success with his [[LL Cool J]] [[diss (music)
column2: diss track]], \"[[Second Round K.O.]]\", which was included on ''Can-I-Bus'', with additional support from heavyweight boxer [[Mike Tyson]].

column1: However, the album received mixed reviews. The beats, created mostly by [[Wyclef Jean]], were criticized for their blandness and unoriginality (with a fair amount of the criticism coming from Canibus), but lyrically, the album was praised. Tower Records referred to Canibus as \"one of the most innovative new MCs in hip-hop. With ''Can-I-Bus'', the debut album, Canibus delivers more of the battle-rhyme lyrics that are his stock in trade. Still, he manages to cover new ground with conceptually strong cuts like 'I Honor U,' which is dedicated to his mother. With his lyrical skills, Canibus represents the elements that helped build rap music.\" The album was [[gold certification
column2: certified gold]] by the [[RIAA]]. The song \"How We Roll\" also appeared on the bonus 3rd disc of Eightball's album ''[[Lost (Eightball album)
music critic]]s who admired Canibus' battle rap skills but felt exhaustive at times, along with subpar production and half-hearted attempts at different topics.

column1: Hugo Lunny of MVRemix praised Canibus' battle rhymes but felt that the production didn't give them the necessary energy needed, highlighting \"I Honor U\" and \"Channel Zero\" for finding the right balance, concluding that \"Overall, this is a good album, although anyone who's heard Canibus on 'Desperados' or 'Making A Name 4 Ourselves' is likely to find the album a bit too over hyped. However, listen to the album with fair expectations, and you'll enjoy it.\"<ref name=\"MVR\"/> [[David Browne (journalist)
column2: David Browne]], writing for ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'', praised Canibus for being able to go beyond the battle rapper image and show versatility in his topics but found the production a hindrance to his goal, concluding that \"His devotion to the lyrical slam and to self-respect earmark Canibus as a contender, but it wouldn’t hurt him to learn a few things about record making–from, say, [[LL Cool J
column3: LL]]?\"<ref name=\"EW\"/> [[AllMusic]]'s [[Stephen Thomas Erlewine]] found Canibus' aggro delivery tiring at times no matter the beat or subject but still gave credit for remaining impactful, concluding that \"Unfortunately, those moments only occur sporadically over the course of this overlong debut, but when they do happen, it's easy to see what all the hype is about.\"<ref name=\"AM\"/>

column1: Wall of Sound's Oliver Wang felt that [[Wyclef Jean]] and [[Jerry Wonda]]'s pop-sounding production didn't suit Canibus' tight flow and dark lyricism and preferred [[Clark Kent (producer)
column2: Clark Kent]], [[Salaam Remi]] and LG as being a perfect match for his content, saying that \"Like his West Coast counterpart, [[Ras Kass]], Canibus proves that his rhyme rep isn't totally fabricated, but both artists blow their bets in trying to appeal to both underground and pop audiences.\"<ref name=\"WofS\"/> Kevin Powell of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' felt the album lacked more personal tracks and intellectual insight to clear up the lyrical venom found throughout, concluding that \"In these smoke-filled last days of the 1990s, Canibus and ''Can-I-Bus'' are exactly what much of hip-hop has become: a lot of hype. Don't believe it.\"<ref name=\"RS\"/> DJ Fatboy of ''RapReviews'' found the album a big disappointment, criticizing Canibus for trying to change his hardcore lyricist image in order to appeal to a mainstream audience, saying that \"It's as if he's embarrassed to be known as a battle rapper. What's wrong with that? Sure, it's a one note performance, but if he can play that one note better than all the other herbs out there, then he shouldn't waste his time and ours by switching up to a style he can't rock.\"<ref name=\"RR\"/>

column2: A Kid Called Roots, Canibus (co-producer), [[Jerry Wonda]]

*\"Gone! The Promises of Yesterday\" by [[The Mad Lads]]
*\"Streets of Cairo of the Poor Little Country Maid\" by [[Sol Bloom]]

column7: archivedate = 2007-10-18}}</ref> (November 24, 1983 – April 12, 2020<ref>[https://www.timeswv.com/sports/former-wvu-linebacker-mclee-dies-at-age-36/article_f69c9368-7d16-11ea-936f-0f8c7c757541.html Former WVU linebacker McLee dies at age 36]</ref> ) was an [[American football]] [[linebacker]]. He played collegiately at [[West Virginia University]].

column1: McLee played for the [[St. Louis Rams]] of the NFL and the [[Calgary Stampeders]] of the CFL.
During high school in Uniontown, PA (suburban Pittsburgh), McLee rushed for 1,637 yards and led the team in [[Tackle (football move)
Following his uncle Billy and cousin Reggie McLee's footsteps, McLee attended [[West Virginia University]]. He was interested in [[Michigan State]] and [[University of Pittsburgh
column2: Pittsburgh]], but neither one gave him offers. McLee redshirted his 2002 freshman year, learning the complex 3-3-5 defensive scheme, but was rookie of the week in practice during the game week against the [[Miami Hurricanes football

column1: In [[2002 NCAA Division I-A football season
column2: 2002]], McLee red-shirted his true freshman season.

column1: In [[2003 NCAA Division I-A football season
column2: 2003]], McLee got more playing time with the graduation of [[Grant Wiley]], 2002's starting linebacker. Behind linebacker Scott Gyorko, McLee totaled 46 tackles for the year and three sacks. McLee recorded two tackles against [[Wisconsin Badgers football
column3: Wisconsin]], three tackles and a sack in the game against the [[Cincinnati Bearcats football
column4: Cincinnati]], and six tackles, a sack, and a fumble recovery against the [[Maryland Terrapins football
column5: Maryland]]. McLee also forced fumble against Miami and [[Virginia Tech Hokies football
column6: Virginia Tech]]. In the [[Gator Bowl]], McLee recorded six tackles.

column1: In [[2004 NCAA Division I-A football season
column2: 2004]], McLee played on the Mountaineer team that was expected to be National Championship contenders with [[Rasheed Marshall]], [[Adam Jones (American football)
column4: Chris Henry]], and [[Kay-Jay Harris]]. Although the Mountaineers ended 8-4, McLee had a good season. McLee shared time with fellow junior Jeff Noechel, but recorded 44 tackles on the year. In an overtime win against Maryland, McLee recorded six tackles and forced a fumble. Against Virginia Tech, McLee led the team with 11 tackles and recorded a 10-yard sack against [[Boston College Eagles football
column5: Boston College]]. McLee had a team-best eight tackles in the [[Gator Bowl]] loss to [[Florida State Seminoles football

column1: In [[2005 NCAA Division I-A football season
column2: 2005]], McLee teamed up with a strong defense of [[Mike Lorello]] and [[Jahmile Addae]] at safeties. McLee earned 2005 first-team All-[[Big East Conference (1979–2013)
column3: Big East]] honors, [[ESPN]] All-Conference honors, and All-[[Eastern College Athletic Conference
column4: ECAC]] honors as the starter. McLee recorded 78 tackles, which was second-best on the team. McLee had a team-high six tackles at [[Syracuse Orange#Football history
column5: Syracuse]] for the season-opener, a team-best 11 tackles in the [[East Carolina Pirates football
column6: East Carolina]] win, team-best nine tackles and a sack of [[Marcus Vick]] against Virginia Tech, 10 tackles and two pass break-ups in overtime win against the [[Louisville Cardinals football
column8: UConn]], and was the leading tackler with 11 tackles against Pitt. McLee won Girdiron Gladiator Award from the West Virginia coaches and was the Big East player of the week against Cincinnati. He was also named MVP on defense against Syracuse, Virginia Tech, Cincinnati, and Pitt.

column1: In [[2006 NCAA Division I-A football season
column2: 2006]], McLee finally started the whole season. He finished the season with 79 tackles but no sacks. McLee had his second career interception against Connecticut, which he returned for 10 yards. McLee had 9 tackles against [[Marshall University#Athletics
column3: Marshall]], six tackles against Maryland, six against Syracuse, six against Connecticut, six against Cincinnati, and eight tackles in the overtime win against [[Rutgers Scarlet Knights football
column4: Rutgers]]. McLee finished the season on the [[Butkus Award]] list and traveled to the [[Senior Bowl]].<ref>[http://www.nfl-draft-site.com/2007/01/official-senior-bowl-roster.html The NFL Draft Site: Official Senior Bowl Roster]</ref> In his final game as a Mountaineer, McLee totaled three tackles against [[2006 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team

column1: During the Senior Bowl, McLee was reported to be \"looking quick\". ESPN ranked McLee as the #14 inside linebacker in the class, out of the 29-ranked inside linebacker prospects. His toughness was praised, while his discipline and learning of schemes were issues. McLee played all three linebacking positions in college, which NFL scouts praised.

McLee went undrafted in the [[2007 NFL Draft]]. A day later, McLee signed with the [[St. Louis Rams]], who did not take any linebackers in the draft, as an undrafted free agent. \"It's a slap in the face,\" McLee said. \"Not one of us was drafted. It's very disappointing. We're going to show the league that we can play... They're going to notice us.\"
On July 18, 2007, McLee's father, Kevin McLee Sr.,<ref name=Kevin /> who was a running back at [[University of Georgia
column3: Tampa Bay Buccaneer]]<ref name=\"Kevin \"/> died at the age of 52.<ref name=\"McLee Sr.\">{{cite web
column6: title = Ex-Georgia RB, Uniontown native McLee dies at 52 - Tribune-Review

column1: In October 2007, McLee was charged with intent to deliver [[cocaine]] and [[marijuana]] and several traffic violations.<ref>[http://www.pittsburghlive.com/x/dailycourier/news/s_552637.html Waives hearing - PittsburghLIVE.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]{{Dead link
column4: fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The charges were dropped on February 12, 2008. The charges where however were refiled on February 18.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: Following being cut by the St. Louis Rams, McLee was signed by the Calgary Stampeders of the [[Canadian Football League]] to a one-year deal. He reported that the [[Green Bay Packers]] were interested in him after his season with Calgary. McLee was later released by Calgary.

In 2008, he played in the [[af2]] (a sort of \"farm league\" for the [[Arena Football League]]) with the [[Iowa Barnstormers]] and the [[Green Bay Blizzard]].<ref name=\"'Eers in Pros Profile\">[http://eersinpros.blogspot.com/search/label/Boo%20Mclee 'Eers in Pros Profile]</ref>
Mclee was drafted into the newly created [[United National Gridiron League]] by [[Team Louisiana]]<ref name=\"'Eers in Pros Profile\"/>
In 2016, McLee was charged in a string of bank robberies in [[Pittsburgh]] and [[Crafton, Pennsylvania]].<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Former Mountaineers linebacker charged in string of bank robberies
column6: access-date=April 13, 2020}}</ref> He pleaded guilty in 2019.<ref name=\"TimesWV\">{{cite web
column8: title=Former WVU linebacker McLee dies at age 36

column7: archivedate = 2007-10-18}}</ref> (November 24, 1983 – April 12, 2020<ref>[https://www.timeswv.com/sports/former-wvu-linebacker-mclee-dies-at-age-36/article_f69c9368-7d16-11ea-936f-0f8c7c757541.html Former WVU linebacker McLee dies at age 36]</ref> ) was an [[American football]] [[linebacker]]. He played collegiately at [[West Virginia University]].

column1: McLee played for the [[St. Louis Rams]] of the NFL and the [[Calgary Stampeders]] of the CFL.
During high school in Uniontown, PA (suburban Pittsburgh), McLee rushed for 1,637 yards and led the team in [[Tackle (football move)
Following his uncle Billy and cousin Reggie McLee's footsteps, McLee attended [[West Virginia University]]. He was interested in [[Michigan State]] and [[University of Pittsburgh
column2: Pittsburgh]], but neither one gave him offers. McLee redshirted his 2002 freshman year, learning the complex 3-3-5 defensive scheme, but was rookie of the week in practice during the game week against the [[Miami Hurricanes football

column1: In [[2002 NCAA Division I-A football season
column2: 2002]], McLee red-shirted his true freshman season.

column1: In [[2003 NCAA Division I-A football season
column2: 2003]], McLee got more playing time with the graduation of [[Grant Wiley]], 2002's starting linebacker. Behind linebacker Scott Gyorko, McLee totaled 46 tackles for the year and three sacks. McLee recorded two tackles against [[Wisconsin Badgers football
column3: Wisconsin]], three tackles and a sack in the game against the [[Cincinnati Bearcats football
column4: Cincinnati]], and six tackles, a sack, and a fumble recovery against the [[Maryland Terrapins football
column5: Maryland]]. McLee also forced fumble against Miami and [[Virginia Tech Hokies football
column6: Virginia Tech]]. In the [[Gator Bowl]], McLee recorded six tackles.

column1: In [[2004 NCAA Division I-A football season
column2: 2004]], McLee played on the Mountaineer team that was expected to be National Championship contenders with [[Rasheed Marshall]], [[Adam Jones (American football)
column4: Chris Henry]], and [[Kay-Jay Harris]]. Although the Mountaineers ended 8-4, McLee had a good season. McLee shared time with fellow junior Jeff Noechel, but recorded 44 tackles on the year. In an overtime win against Maryland, McLee recorded six tackles and forced a fumble. Against Virginia Tech, McLee led the team with 11 tackles and recorded a 10-yard sack against [[Boston College Eagles football
column5: Boston College]]. McLee had a team-best eight tackles in the [[Gator Bowl]] loss to [[Florida State Seminoles football

column1: In [[2005 NCAA Division I-A football season
column2: 2005]], McLee teamed up with a strong defense of [[Mike Lorello]] and [[Jahmile Addae]] at safeties. McLee earned 2005 first-team All-[[Big East Conference (1979–2013)
column3: Big East]] honors, [[ESPN]] All-Conference honors, and All-[[Eastern College Athletic Conference
column4: ECAC]] honors as the starter. McLee recorded 78 tackles, which was second-best on the team. McLee had a team-high six tackles at [[Syracuse Orange#Football history
column5: Syracuse]] for the season-opener, a team-best 11 tackles in the [[East Carolina Pirates football
column6: East Carolina]] win, team-best nine tackles and a sack of [[Marcus Vick]] against Virginia Tech, 10 tackles and two pass break-ups in overtime win against the [[Louisville Cardinals football
column8: UConn]], and was the leading tackler with 11 tackles against Pitt. McLee won Girdiron Gladiator Award from the West Virginia coaches and was the Big East player of the week against Cincinnati. He was also named MVP on defense against Syracuse, Virginia Tech, Cincinnati, and Pitt.

column1: In [[2006 NCAA Division I-A football season
column2: 2006]], McLee finally started the whole season. He finished the season with 79 tackles but no sacks. McLee had his second career interception against Connecticut, which he returned for 10 yards. McLee had 9 tackles against [[Marshall University#Athletics
column3: Marshall]], six tackles against Maryland, six against Syracuse, six against Connecticut, six against Cincinnati, and eight tackles in the overtime win against [[Rutgers Scarlet Knights football
column4: Rutgers]]. McLee finished the season on the [[Butkus Award]] list and traveled to the [[Senior Bowl]].<ref>[http://www.nfl-draft-site.com/2007/01/official-senior-bowl-roster.html The NFL Draft Site: Official Senior Bowl Roster]</ref> In his final game as a Mountaineer, McLee totaled three tackles against [[2006 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team

His toughness was praised, while his discipline and learning of schemes were issues. McLee played all three linebacking positions in college, which NFL scouts praised.

McLee went undrafted in the [[2007 NFL Draft]]. A day later, McLee signed with the [[St. Louis Rams]], who did not take any linebackers in the draft, as an undrafted free agent. \"It's a slap in the face,\" McLee said. \"Not one of us was drafted. It's very disappointing. We're going to show the league that we can play... They're going to notice us.\" McLee will join with fellow former-Mountaineer and quarterback [[Marc Bulger]].

column1: '''KS Jastrzębski Węgiel SA''' - is a Polish professional [[volleyball]] team based in [[Jastrzębie-Zdrój]], founded in 1949 under the name ''LZS Jastrzębie''. Since 2004, acting under its present name, and since May 2, 2005 remaining a public company. So far, the team has won a total of twelve medals in the Polish Championship (MP): 1 gold, 3 silver and 8 bronze. The team plays in the top level Polish league, [[PlusLiga]] continuously since 1997.

column3: Jastrzębski Węgiel before the match of [[PlusLiga]] in 2010.]]

column2: 16px]] '''(x1)''' [[2011 FIVB Volleyball Men's Club World Championship

column1: In 2011 club achieved a silver medal of the [[2011 FIVB Volleyball Men's Club World Championship
column2: FIVB World Club Championship 2011]]. In season [[2012–13 PlusLiga
column3: 2012/2013]] Jastrzębski Węgiel won a bronze medal of [[PlusLiga
column4: Polish Championship]]. In 2013/2014 the club advanced to the Final Four of the [[2013–14 CEV Champions League
column5: Champions League]] held in [[Ankara]], [[Turkey]] and after defeating [[VC Zenit Kazan
column6: Zenit Kazan]] won the bronze medal.<ref>[http://www.zenit-kazan.com/eng/news/?id=147 ''JASTRZEBSKI edge former champions Zenit to strike first CL medal''] – zenit-kazan.com – 23-03-2014</ref><ref>[http://www.jastrzebskiwegiel.pl/jastrzebski_wegiel_trzecia_sila_w_europie_mamy_brazowy_medal_ligi_mistrzow,aktualnosci,1058.html ''Jastrzębski Węgiel trzecią siłą w Europie. Mamy brązowy medal Ligi Mistrzów!!!''] {{webarchive
column8: date=2014-10-31 }} – jastrzebskiwegiel.pl – 23-03-2014</ref> Club ended the season with another bronze in the [[2013–14 PlusLiga
column9: Polish Championship]].<ref>[http://www.przegladsportowy.pl/siatkowka/plusliga,jastrzebski-wegiel-zdobyl-brazowy-medal-mistrzostw-polski-siatkarzy-,artykul,464267,1,904.html ''PlusLiga: Brązowe Jastrzębie''] – przegladsportowy.pl – 28-04-2014</ref> After season 2013/2014 the head coach [[Lorenzo Bernardi]] and one of the club main players [[Michał Kubiak]] left the team.

column2: 2014/2015]] a head coach of the team was Italian [[Roberto Piazza]]. Club led by him took 4th place in [[2014–15 PlusLiga]]. Piazza left the club after that season and has been replaced by Australian coach [[Mark Lebedew]]. Before season [[2015–16 PlusLiga
column3: 2015/2016]] a few main players left the club: previous captain and opposite [[Michal Lasko
column4: Michał Łasko]], opposite [[Mateusz Malinowski]], outside hitter [[Zbigniew Bartman]].

column1: On January 12, the club informed about dismissing a head coach of that time [[Mark Lebedew]] from his post due to weaker sports results, although the team won 2 of 2 group matches in the Champions League and occupied fourth place in the league at the time. The dismissal of the head coach took place two days after losing the quarter-finals of the 2017-18 Polish Cup with ONICO Warszawa (2-3). His duties were taken over by his assistant Leszek Dejewski, and the next official head coach [[Ferdinando De Giorgi]] took over the team on January 21, 2018.<ref>[http://www.plusliga.pl/news/id/33668.html ''Komunikat KS Jastrzębski Węgiel S.A.''] – plusliga.pl – 12-01-2018</ref>

column2: railroad_name=Jacksonville, Tampa and Key West Railway
end_year=1899<!--taken over by the Plant System-->

successor_line=[[Plant System]]
[[Atlantic Coast Line Railroad]]
[[Seaboard Coast Line Railroad]]
[[CSX Transportation]]
map={{Jacksonville, Tampa and Key West Railway}}

column1: The '''Jacksonville, Tampa and Key West Railway''' was a [[railroad]] and [[steamboat]] network in [[Florida]], USA at the end of the 19th century. Most of its lines became part of the [[Plant System]] in 1899 and the [[Atlantic Coast Line Railroad]] in 1902.  The line remains in service today with a vast majority of it now being [[CSX Transportation]]'s [[Sanford Subdivision]].
The '''Tampa, Peace Creek and St. Johns River Railroad''' was incorporated in 1879, and received a charter to build a railroad from [[Jacksonville, Florida
column3: Tampa]]. The Jacksonville, Tampa and Key West Railway was incorporated in 1871, and acquired the railway charter from the Tampa, Peace Creek and St. Johns River Railroad. Construction of a rail line from Jacksonville to [[Palatka, Florida
column4: Palatka]] began in March 1883, and regular service between the cities began in March 1884. The railroad was built to the [[5 ft and 1520 mm gauge railways
column5: 5-foot gauge]] to match that of the [[Plant System]] Waycross and Florida Railroad, with which it connected in Jacksonville. The Jacksonville, Tampa and Key West Railway extended its line from Palatka to [[Sanford, Florida
column6: Sanford]] in 1885, using the right-of-way of the '''Palatka and Indian River Railway Company'''. The line crossed the [[St. Johns River]] a few miles south of Palatka and ran southward on the east side of the river to the northern end of [[Lake Monroe (Florida)
column7: Lake Monroe]], crossed back over the river and then ran a few miles to Sanford, where it connected to the [[South Florida Railroad]]. The line to Sanford began regular service in February 1886.<ref name=Pettengill>{{Cite book
column11: title=The Story of the Florida Railroads 1834–1903
column12: publisher=The Southeast Chapter of The Railway & Locomotive Historical Society, Inc.
column15: series=Bulletin of the Railway & Locomotive Historical Society, Inc.

column1: The [[Atlantic Coast, St. Johns and Indian River Railroad]] completed a line from [[Titusville, Florida
column4: Enterprise]], on the eastern shore of Lake Monroe opposite Sanford, in early 1886. The Jacksonville, Tampa and Key West Railway build a {{convert
column7: adj=on}} line to Enterprise from its mainline at [[Benson Junction, Florida
column8: Enterprise Junction]]. The Jacksonville, Tampa and Key West Railway then leased the Atlantic Coast, St. Johns and Indian River Railroad, and purchased all of its rolling stock. The Jacksonville, Tampa and Key West Railway operated the Enterprise to Titusville line as its Indian River Branch.<ref name=Pettengill/>

column1: After leasing the Titusville–Enterprise line of the Atlantic Coast, St. Johns and Indian River Railroad, the Jacksonville, Tampa and Key West Railway began operating steamboats from its dock in Titusville down the Indian River to [[Jupiter, Florida
column2: Jupiter]]. In December 1888, the Jacksonville, Tampa and Key West Railway established the [[Indian River Steamboat Company]] to operate the steamboats, with Mason Young, vice-president of the railway company, servicing as president of the steamboat company.<ref name=\"Florida1891\">{{cite book
column3: author=Railroad Commission of the State of Florida
column7: pages=90–101}}</ref> The [[Jupiter and Lake Worth Railway]] opened in 1889 as a short connection between the Indian River Steamboat Company at Jupiter and the north end of [[Lake Worth, Florida
column8: Lake Worth]], where steamers continued south. The line was abandoned by 1896 after the completion of the parallel [[Florida East Coast Railway]].

column1: The [[Orange Ridge, DeLand and Atlantic Railroad]] Company was a [[3 ft gauge railways
column5: adj=on}} line built in 1885, connecting [[DeLand, Florida
column6: DeLand]] with DeLand Landing on the St. Johns River. The Jacksonville, Tampa and Key West line intersected it {{convert
column8: mile}} from DeLand Landing at [[DeLand Junction]]. The railroad was reincorporated in 1886 as the Deland and St. Johns River Railroad Company and converted to 5-foot gauge to match the Jacksonville, Tampa and Key West Railway.<ref name=Pettengill/>

column1: In 1893 the JT&KW went [[bankrupt]]. The [[Southeastern Railway (Florida)
column2: Southeastern Railway]] bought the line from Enterprise to Titusville in 1899, and later that year sold it to the [[Florida East Coast Railway]]. Also that year, the rest of the system was reincorporated as the Jacksonville and St. Johns River Railway and sold to the [[Savannah, Florida and Western Railway]] (the [[Plant System]]). The Plant System became part of the [[Atlantic Coast Line Railroad]] in 1902. In 1967 the ACL merged into the [[Seaboard Coast Line Railroad]], eventually becoming part of [[CSX]]. The JT&KW is now part of the \"A\" Line, one of CSX's two main lines into Florida.<ref name=\"CSX\">[http://www.multimodalways.org/docs/railroads/companies/CSX/CSX%20ETTs/CSX%20Jacksonville%20Div%20ETT%20%234%201-1-2005.pdf CSX Jacksonville Division Timetable]</ref>

column1: The [[Orange Ridge, DeLand and Atlantic Railroad]] was incorporated by Laws of Florida Chapter 3332, No. 114 on March 7, 1881, running from [[DeLand, Florida
column2: DeLand]] west across the JT&KW at [[DeLand Junction]] to the [[St. Johns River]]. It became the [[De Land and St. Johns River Railroad]] in 1886, and the JT&KW bought it in 1890.

column1: The [[Enterprise Branch]] ran from the main line at [[Benson Junction]] east to [[Enterprise, Florida
column3: Titusville]] as the [[Atlantic Coast, St. Johns and Indian River Railroad]], acquired in 1886.

column1: The [[Sanford and Lake Eustis Railroad]] was organized in 1886 and merged into the JT&KW on May 1, 1890. The line ran west from Sanford to [[Tavares (FL)

The Jacksonville, Tampa and Key West Railway remains in service and is today part of CSX's A Line.  CSX has designated it as their Sanford Subdivision and [[Jacksonville Terminal Subdivision]].  Though as of 2011, the [[Florida Department of Transportation]] owns a short segment of the line south of [[Deland, Florida
column2: Deland]] to Sanford and operates the [[SunRail]] commuter rail service over that segment.  CSX still runs local freight on the line but all through freight trains have since been shifted to the [[Florida Central and Peninsular Railroad
column3: S Line]] due to SunRail service.  Prior to the sale of the southern portion of the line to FDOT, CSX's Sanford Subdivision continued south to Sanford and then along on the former [[South Florida Railroad]] as far as [[Auburndale, Florida

column1: [[Amtrak]] also uses the line for all of its Florida service including the [[Silver Meteor]], [[Silver Star (Amtrak train)

column5: 5-foot gauge]] to match that of the [[Plant System]] Waycross and Florida Railroad, with which it connected in Jacksonville. The Jacksonville, Tampa and Key West Railway extended its line from Palatka to [[Sanford, Florida
column6: Sanford]] in 1885, using the right-of-way of the '''Palatka and Indian River Railway Company'''. The line crossed the [[St. Johns River]] a few miles south of Palatka and ran southward on the east side of the river to the northern end of [[Lake Monroe (Florida)
column7: Lake Monroe]], crossed back over the river and then ran a few miles to Sanford, where it connected to the [[South Florida Railroad]]. The line to Sanford began regular service in February 1886.<ref name=Pettengill>{{Cite book
column11: title=The Story of the Florida Railroads 1834–1903
column12: publisher=The Southeast Chapter of The Railway & Locomotive Historical Society, Inc.
column15: series=Bulletin of the Railway & Locomotive Historical Society, Inc.

column1: The [[Atlantic Coast, St. Johns and Indian River Railroad]] completed a line from [[Titusville, Florida
column4: Enterprise]], on the eastern shore of Lake Monroe opposite Sanford, in early 1886. The Jacksonville, Tampa and Key West Railway build a {{convert
column7: adj=on}} line to Enterprise from its mainline at [[Benson Junction, Florida
column8: Enterprise Junction]]. The Jacksonville, Tampa and Key West Railway then leased the Atlantic Coast, St. Johns and Indian River Railroad, and purchased all of its rolling stock. The Jacksonville, Tampa and Key West Railway operated the Enterpise to Titusville line as its Indian River Branch.<ref name=Pettengill/>

column1: After leasing the Titusville–Enterprise line of the Atlantic Coast, St. Johns and Indian River Railroad, the Jacksonville, Tampa and Key West Railway began operating steamboats from its dock in Titusville down the Indian River to [[Jupiter, Florida
column2: Jupiter]]. In December 1888, the Jacksonville, Tampa and Key West Railway established the [[Indian River Steamboat Company]] to operate the steamboats, with Mason Young, vice-president of the railway company, servicing as president of the steamboat company.<ref name=\"Florida1891\">{{cite book
column3: author=Railroad Commission of the State of Florida
column7: pages=90–101}}</ref> The [[Jupiter and Lake Worth Railway]] opened in 1889 as a short connection between the Indian River Steamboat Company at Jupiter and the north end of [[Lake Worth, Florida
column8: Lake Worth]], where steamers continued south. The line was abandoned by 1896 after the completion of the parallel [[Florida East Coast Railway]].

column1: The [[Orange Ridge, DeLand and Atlantic Railroad]] Company was a [[3 ft gauge railways
column5: adj=on}} line built in 1885, connecting [[DeLand, Florida
column6: DeLand]] with DeLand Landing on the St. Johns River. The Jacksonville, Tampa and Key West line intersected it {{convert
column8: mile}} from DeLand Landing at [[DeLand Junction]]. The railroad was reincorporated in 1886 as the Deland and St. Johns River Railroad Company and converted to 5-foot gauge to match the Jacksonville, Tampa and Key West Railway.<ref name=Pettengill/>

column1: In 1893 the JT&KW went [[bankrupt]]. The [[Southeastern Railway (Florida)
column2: Southeastern Railway]] bought the line from Enterprise to Titusville in 1899, and later that year sold it to the [[Florida East Coast Railway]]. Also that year, the rest of the system was reincorporated as the Jacksonville and St. Johns River Railway and sold to the [[Savannah, Florida and Western Railway]] (the [[Plant System]]). The Plant System became part of the [[Atlantic Coast Line Railroad]] in 1902. In 1967 the ACL merged into the [[Seaboard Coast Line Railroad]], eventually becoming part of [[CSX]]. The JT&KW is now part of the \"A\" Line, one of CSX's two main lines into Florida.<ref name=\"CSX\">[http://www.multimodalways.org/docs/railroads/companies/CSX/CSX%20ETTs/CSX%20Jacksonville%20Div%20ETT%20%234%201-1-2005.pdf CSX Jacksonville Division Timetable]</ref>

column1: The [[Orange Ridge, DeLand and Atlantic Railroad]] was incorporated by Laws of Florida Chapter 3332, No. 114 on March 7, 1881, running from [[DeLand, Florida
column2: DeLand]] west across the JT&KW at [[DeLand Junction]] to the [[St. Johns River]]. It became the [[De Land and St. Johns River Railroad]] in 1886, and the JT&KW bought it in 1890.

column1: The [[Enterprise Branch]] ran from the main line at [[Benson Junction]] east to [[Enterprise, Florida
column3: Titusville]] as the [[Atlantic Coast, St. Johns and Indian River Railroad]], acquired in 1886.

column1: The [[Sanford and Lake Eustis Railroad]] was organized in 1886 and merged into the JT&KW on May 1, 1890. The line ran west from Sanford to [[Tavares (FL)

The Jacksonville, Tampa and Key West Railway remains in service and is today part of CSX's A Line.  CSX has designated it as their Sanford Subdivision and [[Jacksonville Terminal Subdivision]].  Though as of 2011, the [[Florida Department of Transportation]] owns a short segment of the line south of [[Deland, Florida
column2: Deland]] to Sanford and operates the [[SunRail]] commuter rail service over that segment.  CSX still runs local freight on the line but all through freight trains have since been shifted to the [[Florida Central and Peninsular Railroad
column3: S Line]] due to SunRail service.  Prior to the sale of the southern portion of the line to FDOT, CSX's Sanford Subdivision continued south to Sanford and then along on the former [[South Florida Railroad]] as far as [[Auburndale, Florida

column1: [[Amtrak]] also uses the line for all of its Florida service including the [[Silver Meteor]], [[Silver Star (Amtrak train)

column1: '''Bruce Cannon Gibney''' (born February 16, 1976)<ref>[https://www.macleans.ca/culture/books/qa-a-gen-x-venture-capitalist-on-how-boomers-wrecked-america/ Q&A: A venture capitalist on how boomers wrecked America]</ref><ref>United States Public Records, 1970-2009 (California, 2002-2008)</ref> is an American writer and [[venture capital]]ist. He was one of the first investors at PayPal, and went on to work for PayPal founder [[Peter Thiel]]'s hedge fund Clarium and his venture capital company [[Founders Fund]]. His first book, ''A Generation of Sociopaths: How the Baby Boomers Betrayed America'', was published by [[Hachette (publisher)

Gibney started investing when his [[Stanford University]] roommate [[Ken Howery]] co-founded [[PayPal]], the electronic payments company, and offered Gibney the chance to buy \"friends and family\" shares.<ref>{{cite web
column8: accessdate=March 15, 2016}}</ref> After investing in PayPal, Gibney worked as a litigator but was soon hired by [[Peter Thiel]] after Thiel sold PayPal to [[eBay]] in 2002. Gibney worked at Thiel's [[hedge fund]], Clarium, until 2008, making occasional private investments including in [[Palantir Technologies]] in 2005 and later in [[DeepMind]], which was acquired by [[Google]]<ref>{{Cite news
column10: title=Google buys UK artificial intelligence startup Deepmind for £400m
column15: access-date=January 12, 2017}}</ref> for around $450 million in 2014. He then moved to [[Founders Fund]], a venture capital fund started by Thiel. Thiel and Founders Fund were the earliest outside investors in Facebook, [[SpaceX]], and Palantir, and made other investments including in [[Airbnb
column17: AbbVie]] acquired for $10 billion a few years after Founders Fund's investment.<ref>{{Cite web
column19: title=A startup that just launched out of stealth a few months ago thinks it's found a way to treat cancer, and it just got bought for up to $10 billion

column1: Gibney wrote Founders Fund's controversial statement of ideology, ''What Happened to the Future?'', in 2011, which called for more aggressive investments in breakthrough technologies and became a widely cited article in the technology community.<ref>{{Cite web
column11: title=Facebook Investor Wants Flying Cars, Not 140 Characters
column19: title=Why We Can't Solve Big Problems
column27: title=Our favorite tech long reads of 2011
column33: access-date=January 6, 2017}}</ref> He also wrote other articles about start-ups and technology and lectured on these subjects, as well as Silicon Valley’s \"libertarian problem\".<ref>{{cite web
column57: title=Four Things to Get Right When Starting a Company
column65: title=The HBR List of Audacious Ideas
column71: access-date=October 20, 2016}}</ref> Gibney left Founders Fund in December 2012.<ref>{{cite news
column75: title= Founders Fund Partner Bruce Gibney Has Left The Firm
column77: accessdate= January 17, 2017 }}</ref> He continued to make personal investments, though he made few since 2015, stating in a January 2016 speech in [[Zurich]] that he believes start-ups are richly valued and expressing concern that too many start-ups are remaining private for too long, creating misalignment of incentives between executives and employees and investors.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: Gibney's first book, ''A Generation of Sociopaths: How the Baby Boomers Betrayed America'', linked American stagnation to the [[baby boomers]], characterizing the generation as being unusually prone to anti-social personality disorder, which Gibney believes unraveled the pro-social, pro-growth policies of mid-20th-century America.

In her review for ''[[The Guardian]]'', [[Pulitzer Prize for Fiction]]–winning novelist [[Jane Smiley]] praised Gibney's \"wry, amusing style\", noting that \"he is at his best analysing the financial details of the various forms of national and environmental debt that our children and grandchildren will eventually have to pay.\"<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=A Generation of Sociopaths review – how Trump and other Baby Boomers ruined the world
column10: issn=0261-3077}}</ref> She concluded that \"Gibney does convince me that those of us born between 1940 and 1965 (his definition) are a drag on the future.\"<ref>{{Cite news
column12: title=A Generation of Sociopaths review – how Trump and other Baby Boomers ruined the world
column19: issn=0261-3077}}</ref> In her summer book list review for the ''[[Financial Times]]'', [[Merryn Somerset Webb]] called ''A Generation of Sociopaths'' \"convincing stuff. Look around you in the UK and you will see hints of the same thing: our own boomers aren't rushing to give up any of their goodies for the young. Anyone in any doubt need only ask a dinner party of them how they feel about capital gains tax on primary residences or worse, asking pensioners to help finance their own medical care by paying national insurance.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column21: title=We're going to hell in a handcart- but whose fault is it?

column1: In his review in ''[[The Washington Post]]'', [[Dana Milbank]] wrote that although Gibney overstated his case concerning the Boomers, \"The core of Gibney's argument, that the boomers are guilty of 'generational plunder,' is spot-on.\"<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=If America’s messed up, blame it on the boomers
column9: issn=0190-8286}}</ref> ''[[Booklist]]'' described the book as \"informative, provocative, and entertaining\" in its review.<ref>{{Cite web
column11: title=Booklist Review: A Generation of Sociopaths
column16: access-date=2017-03-02}}</ref> ''[[Kirkus Reviews]]'' called the book an \"endless, broadest-possible-brush harangue\" that has \"some points, all of which would have been better made without assigning damning agency to them: of course health care has to be restructured, and of course taxes have to be raised if the nation is to escape insolvency. His prescriptions on those fronts are sound, though some are surely controversial.\"<ref>{{cite web
column18: title=Kirkus Review: A Generation of Sociopaths
