column1: Composer Andrew Staniland was born in [[Red Deer, Alberta
column2: Red Deer]], [[Alberta]], in 1977. His first instrument was the [[guitar]], and he began playing in [[Heavy metal music
column3: heavy-metal]] bands as a young teen. Staniland began formal studies in jazz and arranging at Grant MacEwan Community College in Edmonton (now [[MacEwan University]]), where he also studied composition with Gordon Nicholson. He then studied [[classical guitar]] at the [[University of Lethbridge]], Alberta, before obtaining both a [[Master's degree
column4: Master's]] and [[Doctorate]] degree in Composition from the [[University of Toronto]].<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web
column6: title=Andrew Staniland accelerates toward the next idea

column1: A composer whose work has been performed and broadcast in over 35 countries,<ref name=\":3\" /> Staniland has been commissioned by musicians and ensembles such as cellist [[Frances-Marie Uitti]], Duo Concertante (violinist [[Nancy Dahn]] and pianist Timothy Steeves), the [[Gryphon Trio]], and [[Les Percussions de Strasbourg]]. He has also been an Affiliate Composer with both the [[National Arts Centre Orchestra]] (2002-2004) and the [[Toronto Symphony Orchestra]] (2006-2009), and in 2005 was a [[Artist-in-residence
column3: Centre de Création Musicale Iannis Xenakis]] in Paris.<ref name=\":12\">{{Cite web

column1: In 2010 Staniland joined the faculty of the [[Music school
column2: School of Music]] at Memorial University of Newfoundland,<ref name=\":0\" /> where he teaches composition and electronic music. There Staniland founded the Memorial ElectroAcoustic Research Lab (MEARL),<ref name=\":2\" /> where he is part of a cross-disciplinary research team that has created the Mune, an electronic music performance instrument that \"combines the functionality of a [[MIDI controller]] ... with the expressiveness and simplicity of an acoustic instrument.\"<ref>{{Cite web

column1: Staniland is an Associate Composer of the [[Canadian Music Centre]],<ref name=\":3\">{{Cite web
column4: last=Canadian Music Centre {{!}} Centre de Musique Canadienne
column12: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref> a member of the [[Canadian League of Composers]],<ref>{{Cite web
column14: title=Current Members {{!}} Canadian League of Composers
column16: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref> and an inaugural member of the College of New Scholars, Artists and Scientists of the [[Royal Society of Canada]].<ref name=\":2\" />

column1: Staniland has been the recipient of many prestigious awards, including a 2018 [[East Coast Music Association
column2: ECMA]] Award for Classical Composition of the Year (for ''The River is Within Us''),<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=ECMA 2018 Wrap-Up: View The Full List Of Winners! - East Coast Music Association
column6: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref> the 2016 Terra Nova Young Innovator Award,<ref>{{Cite web
column17: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref> the National Grand Prize of EVOLUTION (presented in 2009 by [[CBC Music
column19: Espace Musique]] and [[The Banff Centre]]), and the 2004 Karen Keiser Prize in Canadian Music.<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite web
column24: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref> He has also received three [[Juno Award

*''No Labour Saving Machine'' (2012) for tenor and cello
*''Beautymark Aria'' (from ''Dark Star Requiem'') (2010) for soprano and piano
*''Dark Star Requiem'' (2010) operatic oratorio for chamber choir, four soloists (SABB), piano trio and two percussion (Libretto by Jill Battson)
*''At the Laurentian Room'' (2008) for soprano and piano
*''Made in China'' (2008) for tenor, percussion and piano
*''Peter Quince at the Clavier'' (2008) for baritone and piano
*''Road to Berlin'' (2008) for bass and piano
*''Ashlike on the Cradle of the Wind'' (2005) chamber opera (Libretto by Jill Battson)
*''Reflections on O Canada after Truth and Reconciliation'' (2016)
*''(RE)VOLUTION'' (2011) Concerto for electric guitar and orchestra
*''Only Darkness'' (2010) for orchestra and mezzo soprano
*''Variations on a Theme by D.H Lawrence'' (2001) for piano and string orchestra
*''Four Horsemen'' (2012) for symphonic band and electronics

column1: OpIndia was founded in 2014 by Rahul Raj and Kumar Kamal as a current affairs and news website. In October 2016, it was acquired by Kovai Media Private Limited, a [[Coimbatore]]-based company of [[T. V. Mohandas Pai]] that also owns the right-leaning magazine ''[[Swarajya (magazine)
column4: title=Right vs Wrong: Arundhati Roy, Mohandas Pai funding fake news busters

column1: Raj left OpIndia over a disagreement with the site's editorial stance. OpIndia disassociated from Kovai Media and became a separate entity.<ref name=\"Tables Turn\">{{cite web
column3: title=Tables Turn on Twitter's Hindutva Warriors, and It's the BJP Doing the Strong-Arming
column8: The Wire]]}}</ref> [[Rahul Roushan]] was appointed the CEO of OpIndia,<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=OpIndia CEO Rahul Roushan calls for mob violence, deletes tweet
column13: website=[[Alt News]]}}</ref> and Nupur J Sharma became the editor.<ref name=\":2\" />

column1: In a 2018 interview with the ''[[Business Standard]]'', Sharma stated that OpIndia is openly right-leaning and does not claim to be ideologically neutral.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Busting fake news: Who funds whom?
column10: via=[[Rediff.com]]}}</ref> OpIndia has accused prominent media outlets – ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', ''[[India Today]]'', [[Scroll.in]], ''[[The Wire (India)
column11: The Wire]]'', and others – of spreading [[fake news]] and leftist propaganda.<ref name=\":0\">{{cite news
column13: title=Fake news, lies, Muslim bashing, and Ravish Kumar: Inside OpIndia's harrowing world

column1: [[Fact checkers]] certified by the [[Poynter Institute]]'s International Fact-Checking Network (IFCN), including [[Alt News]] and Boom, have identified multiple instances in which OpIndia has propagated fake news.<ref name=\"Fake news\" />
In May 2019, the IFCN rejected OpIndia's application to be accredited as a fact-checker.<ref name=\"ET IFCN\">{{Cite news
column3: title=Can fact-checking emerge as big and viable business?
column8: access-date=10 November 2019}}</ref> While noting partial compliance on a number of categories, the IFCN rejected the application on grounds of political partisanship and lack of transparency, and raised concerns over questionable fact-checking methodologies.<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite web
column10: title=Conclusions and recommendations on the application by OpIndia.com
column18: access-date=12 December 2019}}</ref> The rejection disqualified OpIndia from fact-checking contracts with web properties owned by [[Facebook]] and [[Google]].<ref name=\"ET IFCN\" /> In response, Sharma criticized the IFCN assessment and urged for acceptance of outlets with \"declared ideological leanings\".<ref name=\"ET IFCN\" />

column1: After co-founder Raj departed OpIndia, he described the website as a \"blind mouthpiece\" of the [[Bharatiya Janata Party]] on [[Twitter]] in August 2019. Raj criticized Sharma, alleging that she and others \"started as [[Trolling
column3: play victim card]] when questioned\".<ref name=\"Tables Turn\" />
Nupur Sharma, the actress who starred in [[Hey Bro]]}}

column1: add authority control,safe,Ser Amantio di Nicolao,"'''David Schmader''' is an American writer known for his solo plays, his writing for the Seattle newsweekly ''[[The Stranger (newspaper)
column2: The Stranger]]'', and his annotated screenings of Paul Verhoeven's ''[[Showgirls]]''. He is the author of the 2016 book ''[[Weed: The User's Guide]]''.

column1: Schmader, a solo performer, has created works under the direction of [[Dan Savage]], [[Chay Yew]], and [[Matthew Richter]], with productions at Seattle's [[Hugo House]] literary center<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Classy Talk with David Schmader - Hugo House
column9: title=Enthusiastic crowds find much to like at Bumbershoot '04
column13: title='Straight' Talk on Conversion Therapy / David Schmader's solo show skewers ex-gay movement
column15: access-date=2016-03-02}}</ref> New York CIty's [[Dixon Place]], and the [[Wexner Center for the Arts]]. Outside of full solo productions, Schmader has performed at Seattle's On the Boards<ref>{{Cite web
column17: title=2014 Festival Artists: David Schmader {{!}} On the Boards
column19: access-date=2016-03-02}}</ref> and as a guest of the feminist art-and-performance collective [[Sister Spit]].<ref>{{Cite web
column21: title=Sister Spit {{!}} The Capitol Hill Times

column1: In 1993, Schmader authored the play ''Letter to Axl'', in which he \"uses his autobiographical stories and his obsession with the notoriously homophobic, misogynistic, chemically dependent rock star Axl Rose as a way of examining homophobia, masculinity, and the scary power of the mass media to inspire unrequited love in millions of people.\"<ref>{{Cite web

In his 1999 solo play ''Straight'', Schmader \"takes an undercover excursion into the world of sexual reprogramming...that utilizes Christian fundamentalist ideas in attempt to curb homosexual desires.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column5: access-date=2016-03-02}}</ref> In 2002, ''Straight'' was turned into a performance film which screened at film festivals in Seattle, Austin, Minneapolis, and Washington, D.C.<ref>{{Cite web
column7: title=2002 Seattle Lesbian & Gay Film Festival

column1: ===''A Short-Term Solution to a Long-Term Problem''===

Schmader wrote his third solo play in 2011. ''A Short-Term Solution to a Long-Term Problem'', which Schmader also performed, is \"a comedy about unfunny things: children who die, adults who get sick, and the intricate damage religion can inflict on young people.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=A Short-Term Solution to a Long-Term Problem at Hugo House in Seattle, WA on Sat., Sept. 19, 8 p.m. 2015 - Seattle Theater & Dance Events Calendar - The Stranger

column1: From 1998 through 2014, Schmader served as a writer and editor at the Seattle alternative newsweekly ''[[The Stranger (newspaper)
column2: The Stranger]]'', writing the column \"Last Days: The Week in Review.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title = The Last Days Crisis Is Over (for Me)
column6: access-date = 2016-02-20}}</ref> Schmader also wrote investigative essays on the Michael Jackson 2005 criminal trial and the AVN Awards in Las Vegas.<ref>{{Cite web
column18: last = Schmader}}</ref> With cartoonist [[Ellen Forney]], Schmader created the five-part series \"What the Drugs Taught Me,\" which was reprinted in Forney's 2007 collection ''I Love Led Zeppelin''.<ref>{{Cite web
column19: title = Seattle cartoonist Ellen Forney embraces our oddities
column22: access-date = 2016-02-22}}</ref> Between 2002 and 2004, Schmader curated and hosted Pizzazz!, a citywide talent show produced by ''The Stranger'' and presented on opening night of the [[Bumbershoot
column23: Bumbershoot Arts Festival]].<ref name=\"auto\"/> Schmader writes a cannabis column for ''The Stranger'' {{as of

column1: In 1999, Schmader began hosting screenings of Paul Verhoeven's film ''[[Showgirls]]'', touring his annotated screenings to film festivals and supplying the commentary track for the special-edition ''Showgirls'' DVD<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web
column2: title = 'Showgirls' Bares All in Self-Mocking DVD {{!}} Fox News

column1: Following the decriminalization of recreational marijuana in Washington State, Schmader wrote ''[[Weed: The User's Guide]]'', a handbook for the sane enjoyment of marijuana.<ref>{{Cite web
column2: title = Weed: The User's Guide {{!}} Sasquatch Books
column5: access-date = 2016-02-22}}</ref> ''Weed'' was published in 2016 by [[Sasquatch Books]]. Schmader uses his knowledge of marijuana news and policy in his role as a columnist on [[Leafly]] and a podcast host for the Roll-up.<ref>{{Cite news
column7: title=The Roll-Up #1: Thank You For Sharing That With America {{!}} Leafly

column1: Schmader's plays have received positive reviews from mostly local outlets, including The Stranger, [[Seattle Weekly]], and [[Gothamist
column4: title=‘A Short-Term Solution to a Long-Term Problem’
column8: title=9/11, Showgirls, and Beyonce Clown: David Schmader's Short Term Solution: Seattlest
column10: access-date=2016-03-02}}</ref> Seattle Weekly called 1999's ''Straight'' \"brilliant\" and \"a compassionate, funny, but ardently intelligent exploration of the basic concepts of gender identity.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column14: access-date=2016-03-02}}</ref> Reviewing 2011's A Short-Term Solution to a Long-Term Problem, The Stranger wrote \"[Schmader's] protean wit, his willingness to stare without blinking into howlingly painful emotional cyclones, and his unfailingly calibrated ethical compass are three virtues every writer should strive to emulate.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column16: title=A Short-Term Solution to a Long-Term Problem

column1: Some of Schmader's works have gained recognition nationally, most notably his ''Showgirls'' annotation.<ref>{{Cite web
column7: title=David Schmader's One-Man Demolition of Showgirls, Thursday at Belcourt
column15: title='Showgirls' Bares All in Self-Mocking DVD {{!}} Fox News
column19: access-date=2016-03-02}}</ref> In its review of Schmader's annotation, ''[[The Onion]]''{{'}}s ''[[The A.V. Club
column20: A.V. Club]]'' stated, \"Schmader provides a running commentary on and a deep understanding of these movies' multiple failures—giving them a second, legitimately entertaining life.\"<ref>{{Cite web

column1: Schmader was born in El Paso, Texas. He has BFA in Theater from the [[University of North Carolina School of the Arts]]. In 2015, he became creative director of the nonprofit writing center [[The Greater Seattle Bureau of Fearless Ideas]].<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Our Staff & Leadership {{!}} The Greater Seattle Bureau of Fearless Ideas {{!}} A nonprofit writing and communications center

column1: '''Bradley Steffens''' (born February 10, 1955) is an American poet, playwright, novelist, and author of more than fifty nonfiction books for children and young adults.<ref>\"Library of Congress Online Catalog: Bradley Steffens\". United States Library of Congress.</ref>

In the mid-1970s Steffens self-published two chapbooks of his poetry,<ref>Bradley Steffens, ''From an Eighteenth Century Painted Tile and Other Poems''. San Rafael: Sack Back Publications,1975. Anonymous, ''From the Laguna Beach Pageant of the Masters: An Anonymous Romance of Theatric Space,and Six Anonymous Songs''. San Rafael: Sack Back Publications, 1976. https://books.google.com/books?
ie=UTF8&redirect=true&condition=all</ref> which he sold on the streets of Southern
California. In 1976, the City of [[Laguna Beach, California]], denied Steffens a permit to sell his works within the

city limits, touching off brouhaha in the local press.<ref>Janice Brownfield, ''Reporter vs. Publisher''. Santa Ana, California: Alpenstock Publishing, 1986, pp. 46-47.</ref> Steffens went to court, seeking relief under the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution
column2: First Amendment]], but the court ruled in favor of the city. Steffens turned to writing a series of one-act plays-in-verse,

column1: which were professionally produced as “Herod the Great: A Sequence of Pageants” by the Olympia Arts Ensemble
in Minneapolis in 1981 with [[Michael Yonkers]] in the title role. Noel Bredahl of the ''St. Paul Post-Dispatch'' hailed

the play as \"an awesome creation on the part of the playwright.<ref>Noel BreDahl (April 9, 1981). “What’s playing on area stages.” ''St. Paul Dispatch'', p. 3B.</ref> David Hawley, also of the ''St. Paul Post Dispatch'', wrote, “Steffens is a powerful, talented artist.\"<ref>David Hawley (April 6, 1981). “’Herod’ suffers from uncontrolled excess.” ''St. Paul Post-Dispatch'', p. 14A.</ref>
Steffens has published more than fifty poems over the last forty years, receiving many awards along the way,
including the Emerging Voices Award presented by [[The Loft Literary Center]] in Minneapolis and the Lake Superior
Writing Competition Award sponsored by the [[Duluth Public Library]]. While working as a freelance proofreader

for [[Lucent Books]] in 1989, Steffens wrote his first nonfiction book for children, ''Animal Rights''. Over the next twenty-seven years, he wrote twenty-five more books for children and young adults, coauthored seven, and edited the 2004 anthology ''The Free Speech Movement''. His works have been praised by ''Booklist'', ''School Library Journal'', ''Kirkus Reviews'', and ''Children’s Literature''. ''The Fountain'' called his ''Ibn al-Haytham: First Scientist'' a “beautiful work about Ibn al-Haytham and his advancement of experimental science.”<ref>Ertan Salik (May–June 2008). \"Ibn al-Haytham: First Scientist.\" ''The Fountain''.</ref>

Steffens is a two-time recipient of the San Diego Book Award for Best Young Adult & Children's Nonfiction. His ''Giants'' won the 2005 award<ref>Arthur Salm (May 22, 2006). “San Diego's award-winning writers”. ''San Diego Union Tribune''.</ref> and his ''J.K. Rowling'' received the 2007 prize.<ref>Robert L. Pincus (May 25, 2008). “Steffens takes top honor at book awards bash.” ''San Diego Union Tribune''.</ref> ''J.K. Rowling'' also earned Steffens the Theodor S. Geisel Award for the best published book by a San Diego County author in 2007.<ref>Robert L. Pincus (May 25, 2008). “Steffens takes top honor at book awards bash.” ''San Diego Union Tribune''.</ref> His ''Ibn al-Haytham: First Scientist'' was excerpted in ''Discovery Channel Magazine''<ref>Bradley Steffens (March 2010). “The Optical Scientist”. ''Discovery Channel Magazine'', pp. 90-95.</ref> in March 2010. He was the keynote speaker at the Southeast Regional Conference of [[The Islamic Medical Association of North America]], the Sixth Annual Meeting
of the Muslim Public Affairs Council of Western New York,<ref>Haris Tarin (May 20, 2010). “MPAC-NY Celebrates 6th Anniversary at Annual Dinner.” Muslim Public Affairs
Council.</ref> the Pacifica Institute,<ref>“Lecture Series with Author Bradley Steffens.” Pacifica Institute.</ref> and Women in Dialogue.<ref>First Scientist (March 11, 2010). Gonna Happen.</ref>
*Medical Drones (World of Drones). San Diego: ReferencePoint Press, 2020. {{ISBN
*Social Media Addiction (Risks of Social Media). San Diego: ReferencePoint Press, 2020. {{ISBN
*Marijuana Risks (Drug Risks). San Diego: ReferencePoint Press, 2020. {{ISBN
*J. Cole (Giants of Rap and Hip-Hop). San Diego: ReferencePoint Press, 2020. {{ISBN

'''Bradley Steffens''' (born February 10, 1955) is an American poet, playwright, novelist, and author of more than fifty nonfiction books for children and young adults.<ref>\"Library of Congress Online Catalog: Bradley Steffens\". United States Library of Congress.</ref>

In the mid-1970s Steffens self-published two chapbooks of his poetry,<ref>Bradley Steffens, ''From an Eighteenth Century Painted Tile and Other Poems''. San Rafael: Sack Back Publications,1975. Anonymous, ''From the Laguna Beach Pageant of the Masters: An Anonymous Romance of Theatric Space,and Six Anonymous Songs''. San Rafael: Sack Back Publications, 1976. https://books.google.com/books?
ie=UTF8&redirect=true&condition=all</ref> which he sold on the streets of Southern
California. In 1976, the City of [[Laguna Beach, California]], denied Steffens a permit to sell his works within the

city limits, touching off brouhaha in the local press.<ref>Janice Brownfield, ''Reporter vs. Publisher''. Santa Ana, California: Alpenstock Publishing, 1986, pp. 46-47.</ref> Steffens went to court, seeking relief under the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution
column2: First Amendment]], but the court ruled in favor of the city. Steffens turned to writing a series of one-act plays-in-verse,

column1: which were professionally produced as “Herod the Great: A Sequence of Pageants” by the Olympia Arts Ensemble
in Minneapolis in 1981 with [[Michael Yonkers]] in the title role. Noel Bredahl of the ''St. Paul Post-Dispatch'' hailed

the play as \"an awesome creation on the part of the playwright.<ref>Noel BreDahl (April 9, 1981). “What’s playing on area stages.” ''St. Paul Dispatch'', p. 3B.</ref> David Hawley, also of the ''St. Paul Post Dispatch'', wrote, “Steffens is a powerful, talented artist.\"<ref>David Hawley (April 6, 1981). “’Herod’ suffers from uncontrolled excess.” ''St. Paul Post-Dispatch'', p. 14A.</ref>
Steffens has published more than fifty poems over the last forty years, receiving many awards along the way,
including the Emerging Voices Award presented by [[The Loft Literary Center]] in Minneapolis and the Lake Superior
Writing Competition Award sponsored by the [[Duluth Public Library]]. While working as a freelance proofreader

for [[Lucent Books]] in 1989, Steffens wrote his first nonfiction book for children, ''Animal Rights''. Over the next twenty-seven years, he wrote twenty-five more books for children and young adults, coauthored seven, and edited the 2004 anthology ''The Free Speech Movement''. His works have been praised by ''Booklist'', ''School Library Journal'', ''Kirkus Reviews'', and ''Children’s Literature''. ''The Fountain'' called his ''Ibn al-Haytham: First Scientist'' a “beautiful work about Ibn al-Haytham and his advancement of experimental science.”<ref>Ertan Salik (May–June 2008). \"Ibn al-Haytham: First Scientist.\" ''The Fountain''.</ref>

Steffens is a two-time recipient of the San Diego Book Award for Best Young Adult & Children's Nonfiction. His ''Giants'' won the 2005 award<ref>Arthur Salm (May 22, 2006). “San Diego's award-winning writers”. ''San Diego Union Tribune''.</ref> and his ''J.K. Rowling'' received the 2007 prize.<ref>Robert L. Pincus (May 25, 2008). “Steffens takes top honor at book awards bash.” ''San Diego Union Tribune''.</ref> ''J.K. Rowling'' also earned Steffens the Theodor S. Geisel Award for the best published book by a San Diego County author in 2007.<ref>Robert L. Pincus (May 25, 2008). “Steffens takes top honor at book awards bash.” ''San Diego Union Tribune''.</ref> His ''Ibn al-Haytham: First Scientist'' was excerpted in ''Discovery Channel Magazine''<ref>Bradley Steffens (March 2010). “The Optical Scientist”. ''Discovery Channel Magazine'', pp. 90-95.</ref> in March 2010. He was the keynote speaker at the Southeast Regional Conference of [[The Islamic Medical Association of North America]], the Sixth Annual Meeting
of the Muslim Public Affairs Council of Western New York,<ref>Haris Tarin (May 20, 2010). “MPAC-NY Celebrates 6th Anniversary at Annual Dinner.” Muslim Public Affairs
Council.</ref> the Pacifica Institute,<ref>“Lecture Series with Author Bradley Steffens.” Pacifica Institute.</ref> and Women in Dialogue.<ref>First Scientist (March 11, 2010). Gonna Happen.</ref>

column7: last=Memorial University of Newfoundland School of Music

column1: Composer Andrew Staniland was born in [[Red Deer, Alberta
column2: Red Deer]], [[Alberta]], in 1977. His first instrument was the [[guitar]], and he began playing in [[Heavy metal music
column3: heavy-metal]] bands as a young teen. Staniland began formal studies in jazz and arranging at Grant MacEwan Community College in Edmonton (now [[MacEwan University]]), where he also studied composition with Gordon Nicholson. He then studied [[classical guitar]] at the [[University of Lethbridge]], Alberta, before obtaining both a [[Master's degree
column4: Master's]] and [[Doctorate]] degree in Composition from the [[University of Toronto]].<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web
column6: title=Andrew Staniland accelerates toward the next idea

column1: A composer whose work has been performed and broadcast in over 35 countries,<ref name=\":3\" /> Staniland has been commissioned by musicians and ensembles such as cellist [[Frances-Marie Uitti]], Duo Concertante (violinist [[Nancy Dahn]] and pianist Timothy Steeves), the [[Gryphon Trio]], and [[Les Percussions de Strasbourg]]. He has also been an Affiliate Composer with both the [[National Arts Centre Orchestra]] (2002-2004) and the [[Toronto Symphony Orchestra]] (2006-2009), and in 2005 was a [[Artist-in-residence
column3: Centre de Création Musicale Iannis Xenakis]] in Paris.<ref name=\":12\">{{Cite web

column1: In 2010 Staniland joined the faculty of the [[Music school
column2: School of Music]] at Memorial University of Newfoundland,<ref name=\":0\" /> where he teaches composition and electronic music. There Staniland founded the Memorial ElectroAcoustic Research Lab (MEARL),<ref name=\":2\" /> where he is part of a cross-disciplinary research team that has created the Mune, an electronic music performance instrument that \"combines the functionality of a [[MIDI controller]] ... with the expressiveness and simplicity of an acoustic instrument.\"<ref>{{Cite web

column1: Staniland is an Associate Composer of the [[Canadian Music Centre]],<ref name=\":3\">{{Cite web
column4: last=Canadian Music Centre {{!}} Centre de Musique Canadienne
column12: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref> a member of the [[Canadian League of Composers]],<ref>{{Cite web
column14: title=Current Members {{!}} Canadian League of Composers
column16: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref> and an inaugural member of the College of New Scholars, Artists and Scientists of the [[Royal Society of Canada]].<ref name=\":2\" />

column1: Staniland has been the recipient of many prestigious awards, including a 2018 [[East Coast Music Association
column2: ECMA]] Award for Classical Composition of the Year (for ''The River is Within Us''),<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=ECMA 2018 Wrap-Up: View The Full List Of Winners! - East Coast Music Association
column6: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref> the 2016 Terra Nova Young Innovator Award,<ref>{{Cite web
column17: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref> the National Grand Prize of EVOLUTION (presented in 2009 by [[CBC Music
column19: Espace Musique]] and [[The Banff Centre]]), and the 2004 Karen Keiser Prize in Canadian Music.<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite web
column24: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref> He has also received three [[Juno Award

column1: →‎Career:Correct citation errors (deprecated dead-url parameters), and genfixes,safe,TAnthony,"{{Infobox comedian

'''Dalton Ichiro Tanonaka''' (born June 13, 1954) is an American television executive. He has spent most of his career in Asia, receiving several international and U.S. awards for his journalism work. Tanonaka is also known for his community service, providing scholarships to deserving students and speaking  at schools and universities.<ref>{{harvnb

Tanonaka was born in Kapaau, [[Kohala, Hawaii]], not far from the original statue of [[King Kamehameha I]]. He was raised in Honolulu on the island of Oahu, attending public schools through his graduation from [[Kalani High School]], where he played football and soccer. After working as a tour escort to \"grow up\" and save money, Tanonaka graduated from Mesa College (now [[Colorado Mesa University]]) in [[Grand Junction, Colorado]], in 1976 with an Associate in Arts degree, and [[Northern Illinois University]] in [[DeKalb, Illinois]], in 1977 with a Bachelor of Science degree in journalism.

After TV and newspaper jobs at the ABC and NBC affiliates in Honolulu and the ''[[Honolulu Advertiser]]'', Tanonaka was recruited by Japan's public broadcaster [[NHK]] in 1990. He helped launch and was the anchor of \"Japan Business Today\", an internationally distributed daily program from Tokyo.<ref>{{cite web
After the NHK project ended in 1994, Tanonaka joined the launch team of the U.S. business channel [[CNBC Asia
column2: CNBC in Asia]]. From regional headquarters in Chai Wan, Hong Kong, Tanonaka anchored daily news and feature programs including \"The NBC Asia Evening News\" and \"Money, Money, Money\".

column1: When the operations of CNBC Asia was moved to Singapore in 1998, Tanonaka returned to Hawaii for a brief period. He was appointed Honolulu's director of economic development, where he served until resuming his journalism career in 1999. [[CNN International]] recruited him to its Asia headquarters in Hong Kong, where he anchored programs including \"BizAsia\", \"Asia Tonight\", and \"TalkAsia\".

Following the [[September 11, 2001 attacks]] in the U.S., Tanonaka asked to be released from his CNN contract and returned to Hawaii to make an attempt at public service. In [[Hawaii gubernatorial election, 2002
column2: 2002]], he ran unsuccessfully for the [[Republican Party (United States)
column3: Republican]] nomination for [[Lieutenant Governor of Hawaii]], finishing second behind former [[Hawaii State Circuit Courts
column8: title=Dalton Tanonaka running for Republican lt. governor seat - Thegardenisland.com: News
column9: accessdate=Apr 13, 2020}}</ref> Following a brief period as president of the [[Pacific Basin Economic Council]] (PBEC) based in Honolulu, Tanonaka ran unsuccessfully for the [[United States House of Representatives]] in 2004.<ref>https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/elections/2004/candidates/295076/</ref> During this campaign, allegations of illegalities were made by political opponents. Tanonaka cooperated with authorities, but after agreeing to plead guilty to technical violations, U.S. District Judge [[Helen Gillmor]] ordered him to spend 90 days in the [[Honolulu Federal Detention Center]] to \"send a message\" to the public.

column1: In 2006, Tanonaka joined Indonesia's first 24-hour news channel [[Metro TV (Indonesia)
column6: title=eams Magazine| July - August 2013 | Asia Dr
column7: accessdate=Apr 13, 2020}}</ref>  He was tasked with creating a new international-standard English program for global distribution. \"Indonesia Now\" debuted in September 2006, and is seen on international networks such as Japan's NHK as well as live-streamed on the Internet at www.metrotvnews.com.<ref>{{cite web

column1: In 2010, Tanonaka teamed up with actress Rahayu \"Sara\" Saraswati for the weekly dialogue program \"TalkIndonesia\".  In 2011, he created \"ASEAN Today\", a monthly program done in partnership with the [[Association of Southeast Asian Nations]] (ASEAN) Secretariat.<ref>{{Cite web
column7: url-status=dead }}</ref> Tanonaka was a regular columnist in the ''[[Jakarta Post]]'' \"Weekender\" magazine from its debut in 2007, moving to the ''[[Jakarta Globe]]'' in 2010.<ref>http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/archive/dalton-tanonaka-despite-the-frustrations-35-things-to-love-about-life-in-indonesia/</ref> In January 2014, Tanonaka became CEO of \"[[The Indonesia Channel]],\" the country's first 24-hour all-English channel for global distribution.<ref>{{cite web

column1: Training professional journalists has been a regular part of Tanonaka's career. Under a program coordinated by the Asia-Pacific Institute for Broadcasting Development (AIBD), he has travelled to Iran, Pakistan and Mauritius to hold workshops in broadcasting standards and skills. The Tanonaka International Journalism Scholarship was named for Tanonaka's father Thomas, and given to deserving university students in Indonesia. Winners were handed cash grants and received living stipends in cities such as [[Yogyakarta]], [[Lampung]], and Jakarta, the most recent in June 2013.<ref>{{cite web
column4: accessdate=Sep 13, 2019}}</ref> As a member of the [[Asian American Journalists Association]] (AAJA),{{citation needed
column5: date=February 2020}} Tanonaka created and initially endowed the AAJA Minoru Yasui Memorial Scholarship in memory of [[Minoru Yasui
column6: the late civil rights advocate]]. It was first awarded in 1993 to promising male broadcast students to support and motivate interest in the field.

column1: Tanonaka has also been involved in a variety of other charitable activities in Indonesia. In December 2006, he was the co-creator of the \"Beat The Bird Flu Concert\" in Jakarta, Indonesia, to spotlight prevention measures of the deadly virus. He secured MetroTV's commitment in airing public service announcements and a concert special. An ongoing environmental disaster in [[Sidoarjo Regency
column2: Sidoarjo, East Java]] prompted Tanonaka and friend Ron Mullers to hold a fund-raising event in 2007 for victims of [[Sidoarjo mud flow
column3: an unstoppable mudflow]] that wiped out homes and businesses. After raising nearly $10,000 with the participation of Tanonaka's rock'n'roll band, the men went personally to the mudflow site to personally hand out packets of money directly to affected residents. Finally, to develop and promote Indonesian artists, Tanonaka created \"The Mister Moonlight Show\" in 2009, a live music event with Indonesian musicians and singers for five-star hotel venues. It is now in its fourth year.<ref>{{cite web

column1: Tanonaka and Mullers led a community drive to erect a statue of a young Barack Obama in a park near the U.S. president's childhood home in Jakarta, Indonesia. It was unveiled in December 2009, and moved to its permanent location at Obama's elementary school in February 2010.<ref>{{cite news
Tanonaka is the author of four books, compilations of his newspaper columns chronicling his time in various parts of the world:

* Member of the Year, Asian American Journalists Association, Boston, United States, August 1997
[[Category:Candidates in the 2004 United States elections]]","{{Infobox comedian

'''Dalton Ichiro Tanonaka''' (born June 13, 1954) is an American television executive. He has spent most of his career in Asia, receiving several international and U.S. awards for his journalism work. Tanonaka is also known for his community service, providing scholarships to deserving students and speaking  at schools and universities.<ref>{{harvnb

Tanonaka was born in Kapaau, [[Kohala, Hawaii]], not far from the original statue of [[King Kamehameha I]]. He was raised in Honolulu on the island of Oahu, attending public schools through his graduation from [[Kalani High School]], where he played football and soccer. After working as a tour escort to \"grow up\" and save money, Tanonaka graduated from Mesa College (now [[Colorado Mesa University]]) in [[Grand Junction, Colorado]], in 1976 with an Associate in Arts degree, and [[Northern Illinois University]] in [[DeKalb, Illinois]], in 1977 with a Bachelor of Science degree in journalism.

After TV and newspaper jobs at the ABC and NBC affiliates in Honolulu and the ''[[Honolulu Advertiser]]'', Tanonaka was recruited by Japan's public broadcaster [[NHK]] in 1990. He helped launch and was the anchor of \"Japan Business Today\", an internationally distributed daily program from Tokyo.<ref>{{cite web
After the NHK project ended in 1994, Tanonaka joined the launch team of the U.S. business channel [[CNBC Asia
column2: CNBC in Asia]]. From regional headquarters in Chai Wan, Hong Kong, Tanonaka anchored daily news and feature programs including \"The NBC Asia Evening News\" and \"Money, Money, Money\".

column1: When the operations of CNBC Asia was moved to Singapore in 1998, Tanonaka returned to Hawaii for a brief period. He was appointed Honolulu's director of economic development, where he served until resuming his journalism career in 1999. [[CNN International]] recruited him to its Asia headquarters in Hong Kong, where he anchored programs including \"BizAsia\", \"Asia Tonight\", and \"TalkAsia\".

Following the [[September 11, 2001 attacks]] in the U.S., Tanonaka asked to be released from his CNN contract and returned to Hawaii to make an attempt at public service. In [[Hawaii gubernatorial election, 2002
column2: 2002]], he ran unsuccessfully for the [[Republican Party (United States)
column3: Republican]] nomination for [[Lieutenant Governor of Hawaii]], finishing second behind former [[Hawaii State Circuit Courts
column8: title=Dalton Tanonaka running for Republican lt. governor seat - Thegardenisland.com: News
column9: accessdate=Apr 13, 2020}}</ref> Following a brief period as president of the [[Pacific Basin Economic Council]] (PBEC) based in Honolulu, Tanonaka ran unsuccessfully for the [[United States House of Representatives]] in 2004.<ref>https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/elections/2004/candidates/295076/</ref> During this campaign, allegations of illegalities were made by political opponents. Tanonaka cooperated with authorities, but after agreeing to plead guilty to technical violations, U.S. District Judge [[Helen Gillmor]] ordered him to spend 90 days in the [[Honolulu Federal Detention Center]] to \"send a message\" to the public.

The '''2020–21 Temple Owls men's basketball team''' represents [[Temple University]] during the [[2020–21 NCAA Division I men's basketball season]]. The Owls, led by second-year head coach [[Aaron McKie]], play their home games at the [[Liacouras Center]] in [[Philadelphia]] as a member of the [[American Athletic Conference]].
The [[2019–20 Temple Owls men's basketball team
column2: Owls]] finished the [[2019–20 NCAA Division I men's basketball season
column3: 2019–20 season]] 14–17, 6–12 in [[2019–20 American Athletic Conference men's basketball season
column4: AAC play]] to finish in tenth place. They entered as the No. 10 seed in the [[2020 American Athletic Conference Men's Basketball Tournament
column5: AAC Tournament]], which was ultimately cancelled due to the [[2019–20 coronavirus pandemic

column1: The '''women's featherweight''' is a competition featured at the [[2019 World Taekwondo Championships]], and was held at the [[Manchester Arena]] in [[Manchester]], [[United Kingdom]] on 17 and 18 May. Featherweights were limited to a maximum of 57 kilograms in body mass.

column1: The '''women's featherweight''' is a competition featured at the [[2019 World Taekwondo Championships]], and was held at the [[Manchester Arena]] in [[Manchester]], [[United Kingdom]] on 17 and 18 May. Featherweights were limited to a maximum of 57 kilograms in body mass.

column2: director]], [[writer]], and producer living in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]].{{citation needed

column1: Stern grew up in [[Pleasantville, New York]] and attended Byram Hills High School in [[Armonk, New York]], and then went to film school at [[Tisch School of the Arts]] [[New York University]] (NYU) from 1983–87,{{citation needed
column2: date=November 2014}} where he met [[Alex Winter]].<ref name=\"Farber\" /> The two collaborated on a number of short films including ''Squeal of Death'',<ref name=\"Farber\">{{cite news
column6: title=Alex Winter's 'Idiot Box' Series Unleashes Violence For Laughs
column10: via=[[Chicago Tribune]]}}</ref> which was noticed by an executive at [[Columbia Pictures]] in 1986. After graduating the pair went to Hollywood and directed IMPACT video magazine, which feature artists and performers such as [[Bill Hicks]], Survival Research Labs, [[Public Enemy]], Robert Williams, [[Jane's Addiction]], and another short film with [[Butthole Surfers]].{{citation needed

column1: In 1987 Stern and Winter drove to Hollywood and sent a copy of ''Squeal of Death'' to [[Sam Raimi]], whose film [[Evil Dead 2]] was an inspiration to them. Raimi responded enthusiastically. He and his partner [[Rob Tapert]] optioned an anthology comedy feature film script from Stern and Winter.{{citation needed
column2: date=November 2014}} The pair then worked on a number of short films and music videos for bands such as [[Red Hot Chili Peppers]] and [[Ice Cube]].{{citation needed

column1: Stern and Winter teamed up with writer Tim Burns on ''[[The Idiot Box (MTV)
column6: title=Movie Review: 'Freaked': Potty-Level Humor Mixed With Terrific Effects
column10: accessdate=November 27, 2014}}</ref> with Stern and Winter also co-starring and co-directing.<ref name=\"Farber\" /><ref>{{cite news
column14: title=TV Review: Hey, What's Wrong With a Little Idiotic Stealing Among Friends?

column1: Immediately following ''The Idiot Box'', Stern, Winter and Burns co-wrote the 1993 film ''[[Freaked]]'' with Stern and Winter also serving as co-directors. Freaked starred Winter, [[Randy Quaid]], [[Keanu Reeves]], [[Bobcat Goldthwait]] and [[Mr. T]].<ref name=\"Willman\" /> The film gained a cult following and in 2013 played at [[Cinefamily]] in Los Angeles in celebration of the 20th anniversary of its release.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Heavy Midnites: Freaked (20th Anniv. screening, directors Alex Winter & Tom Stern in person!)

column1: Stern also co-wrote the screenplay to ''[[An American Werewolf in Paris]]'', the sequel to the 1981 film ''[[An American Werewolf in London]]'', with Burns and Anthony Waller.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title= An American Werewolf in Paris

column1: Stern and Burns also collaborated on ''[[The Chimp Channel]]''.<ref>{{Cite journal
Stern has worked with [[Jimmy Kimmel]]'s production company [[Jackhole Productions]] on shows such as ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]'',{{citation needed
column2: date=November 2014}} ''[[The Man Show]]'' as segment director,<ref>{{cite web
column7: accessdate=November 28, 2014}}</ref> and ''[[Crank Yankers]]'' as director and [[Television producer#Types of television producers
column13: accessdate=November 28, 2014}}</ref> In addition, Stern appeared as an actor and worked as a writer for [[Trey Parker]] and [[Matt Stone]]'s presidential parody, ''[[That's My Bush!]]'',<ref>{{cite web
column18: accessdate=November 28, 2014}}</ref> as co-[[executive producer]], served as director and writer for ''[[The Andy Milonakis Show]]'',<ref>{{cite web
column23: accessdate=November 28, 2014}}</ref> and was one of the creators and producers of the [[Comedy Central]] travel show parody ''[[Gerhard Reinke's Wanderlust]]''.<ref>{{cite news
column26: title=Gerhard Reinke's Wanderlust: Full Production Credits

column1: Tom was recently writer/director/producer on a live action SpongeBob Squarepants special starring Tom Kenny, Jon Heder, Rob Riggle, Meghan Trainor and Anthony Davis scheduled to air on Nickelodeon in Jan 2020. Tom was also recently showrunner/director on two Netflix shows: Kevin Hart’s Guide to Black History and The Toys That Made Us. Tom’s short film Adams, which he produced, directed and adapted from the George Saunders story, stars Patton Oswalt and Fred Armisen, and recently won Best Comedy at the HollyShorts Film Festival <ref>http://www.hollyshorts.com/2019-award-winners</ref>, where the jury included Anthony Russo and Matthew Modine. Other recent shows directed by Tom include Comedy Central’s rebooted Crankyankers, Fox’s What Just Happened with Fred Savage <ref>https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/aftershow-spoof-what-just-happened-starring-fred-savage-a-go-at-fox-1205186</ref>, and the Jim Henson Company’s upcoming animatronic alien show for Disney +.
*''[[The Toys That Made Us]]'' (2017) - Director <ref>{{Cite news

column3: title=Kevin Hart To Star In & Produce History Special ‘The Black Man’s Guide To History’

*''[[The Andy Milonakis Show]]'' (2005) - Writer, Director, Executive Producer
*''[[Gerhard Reinke's Wanderlust]]'' (2003) - Writer, Director, Executive Producer

column2: German]] politician and activist. She has been a member of the [[Bundestag]] since 2017, when she was elected on the party list of [[The Left (Germany)
column3: The Left]], without being a party member. Previously, she was a member of the [[Pirate Party Germany]] and the [[Alliance 90/The Greens
column4: Greens]]. She is married to [[Daniel Domscheit-Berg]].<ref name=\"fr\">{{Cite news

column1: Anke Domscheit-Berg grew up the daughter of an art historian and a doctor in [[Müncheberg]] in the then-[[GDR]].<ref>{{cite news
column8: language=de-DE}}</ref> She has a sister and two brothers.<ref>{{cite web
column14: language=de-DE}}</ref> Domscheit-Berg attended a [[Education in East Germany
column15: polytechnic secondary school]], before transferring to an [[Extended Secondary School (East Germany)
column16: extended secondary school]] in [[Strausberg]] to sit the [[Abitur]] examination.<ref>{{cite web
column19: language=de-DE}}</ref> In 1987 she began studying textile art in [[Schneeberg, Saxony]]. Following German reunification, she worked for three years to finance her further studies. In 1993 she began studying [[business economics]] at the [[accadis Hochschule Bad Homburg
column20: International Business School]] in [[Bad Homburg vor der Höhe]], specialising in political economy and international economic relationships as well as the [[Spanish language]]. In 1996 she gained a ''[[Bachelor of Arts]] - International Business Administration'' degree and in the same year completed a [[Master of Business Administration]] degree at [[Northumbria University]].<ref>{{cite web

column1: After graduating she worked as a management consultant at [[Accenture]] and [[McKinsey]]. From 2008 to 2011, Domscheit-Berg was active as a lobbyist for [[Microsoft]] in Germany. Following that, she was self-employed as a writer and businesswoman.<ref>{{cite web
column7: language=de-DE}}</ref> In 2016 she founded [[ViaEuropa]] together with [[Daniel Domscheit-Berg]] and [[Jonas Birgersson]]. The company aims to promote the decentralised development of fibre-optic networks in Germany. In 2017, she stepped down from the position of managing director.{{cn}}

column1: In 2010 she was an honorary supervisory board member of [[Teach First Deutschland]].{{cn}} She was a freelance policy advisor at the [[World Future Council]] on the topic of violence against women and girls and an honorary member of the think-tank of the German NGO [[Welthungerhilfe]].<ref>{{cite web

column9: title=Einladung: Geflüchtete Kinder und Frauen Schützen
column13: language=de}}</ref> In 2015 she was a member of the jury for the {{ill

column1: From June-October 2017 she worked part-time as a research assistant to [[Petra Sitte]], a member of the German [[Bundestag]].<ref>{{cite web
In 2000, Domscheit-Berg gave birth to a son. After separating from the father, she was a single mother for a while.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Die alleinerziehende Mutter ist ein Auslaufmodell. Auch wenn ihr das selbst vielleicht nicht bewusst ist. Und den Vätern erst recht nicht: Niemand allein

column1: Anke Domscheit-Berg was a member of [[Alliance 90/The Greens]] in the [[Mitte]] borough of [[Berlin]].<ref>{{cite web
column6: language=de}</ref> In May 2012 she joined the [[Pirate Party Germany]].<ref>{{cite news
column7: title=Anke Domscheit-Berg wechselt zu den Piraten
column10: language=de}}</ref> From August 2013 to July 2014, Domscheit-Berg was chair of the Pirate Party in [[Brandenburg]].<ref>{{cite news

column1: In the [[2013 German federal election]], Domscheit-Berg was second on the Pirates' party list in Brandenburg, and also stood as a direct candidate in the single-member constituency of [[Oberhavel – Havelland II]].<ref>{{cite news
column2: title=Piraten: Netzaktivistin Domscheit-Berg nur auf Listenplatz zwei
column7: language=de}}</ref> In the [[2014 European Parliament election]], she was third on the Pirate Party's national party list.<ref>{{cite news
column8: title=Piratenpartei: Parteitag in Bochum zur Europawahl
column12: language=de}}</ref> She was however unsuccessful in both elections.

column1: In September 2014, Domscheit-Berg left the Pirate Party.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Der letzte Tropfen war zu viel. Tschüss, Piratenpartei. (archived)
column9: language=de}</ref> In the [[2017 German federal election]], she stood as a candidate for [[The Left (Germany)
column10: The Left]] in the constituency of [[Brandenburg an der Havel – Potsdam-Mittelmark I – Havelland III – Teltow-Fläming I]], without being a party member, as well as taking third place on the party list of [[The Left (Germany)
column16: language=de}}</ref> She was defeated in the consituency by [[Christian Democratic Union of Germany
column17: CDU]] candidate [[Dietlind Tiemann]], but was elected as a member of the Bundestag via the party list. She is the chair of the Left group in the Bundestag's 'Digital Agenda' committee.<ref>{{cite web
column20: title=Wer sitzt im Ausschuss Digitale Agenda?

column4: Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels}}

column2:
editor = Nick Arthurs
St. John O'Rorke
Sue Wyatt

column1: '''''Lock, Stock...''''' is a seven-part British television crime drama series, co-written and created by [[Guy Ritchie]], as a spin-off from his 1998 film ''[[Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels]]''.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Oi! Mate! Wanna buy a spin-off?
column8: accessdate=24 June 2018 }}</ref> The series first broadcast on Channel 4 on 29 May 2000 with a feature-length pilot, ''Lock, Stock and Four Stolen Hooves''.

column1: The series stars [[Daniel Caltagirone]], [[Del Synnott]], [[Scott Maslen]] and [[Shaun Parkes]] as close friends Moon, Jamie, Bacon and Lee,<ref>http://www.bfi.org.uk/films-tv-people/4ce2b839e78c5</ref> who run ''The Lock'', a [[public house]] in [[London]]. Each episode focuses on the four friends attempting a different business venture, and the [[comedy of errors]] that ensues. [[Ralph Brown]] also stars as local gangland boss Miami Vice.

''Lock, Stock...'' was [[Ginger Productions]]' first commission for television.<ref>https://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/how-lock-stock-and-two-smoking-barrels-was-remade-as-a-tv-drama-for-channel-4/1194357.article</ref> The series prominently featured the use of the [[rhyming slang]] of London's [[East End]], making it harder for some viewers to comprehend. In Australia, the series first aired in 2001 on [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation
column2: ABC]]. In [[Portugal]], the series first aired in 2005 on cable channel [[SIC Radical]]. In Germany, the series first aired on cable channel [[RTL Crime (German TV channel)
column3: RTL Crime]] in 2011, under the title  '''''Bube, Dame, König, grAS'''''  (which in turn, is the German title of ''Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels'').

column1: A soundtrack album featuring music used in the series was issued on 9 June 2000 via Virgin Records.<ref>https://www.amazon.co.uk/Lock-Stock-TV-Ost-CASSETTE/dp/B000057UY1/</ref> The complete series was released on DVD [[Universal Studios]] for [[DVD region code#Region codes and countries
column2: Region 2]] on 4 December 2000.<ref>https://www.amazon.co.uk/Lock-Stock-Complete-TV-DVD/dp/B00004YVEM/</ref> The series was later released by Siren Visual Entertainment for [[DVD region code#Region codes and countries
column3: Region 4]] in [[Australia]]. The series is also available to purchase as a box-set on [[iTunes]].<ref>https://itunes.apple.com/au/tv-season/lock-stock-the-complete-tv-series/id446261558</ref>

column1: * [[Ralph Brown]] as Miami Vice; a foul-mouthed local gang lord.
* [[Daniel Caltagirone]] as Moon; a chef and electronics expert.
* [[Scott Maslen]] as Jamie; a fast talker.
* [[Shaun Parkes]] as Bacon; who makes sure things run smoothly, or at least tries to.
* [[Del Synnott]] as Lee; a ladies man, who always has sex on his mind.

column2: Christopher Adamson]] as Three Feet; an enforcer working for Miami Vice.

column1: * [[Lisa Rogers]] as Tanya; a dancer at Lapland.
* Mario Kalli as Kouros; proprietor of the Trojan Kebab House.
* George Antoni as Nefarious; a Cypriot who deals in anything shady from the back of the Trojan Kebab House.
* [[Martin Freeman]] as Jaap; a Dutch drug taker and general idiot.

column2: WrittenBy = Chris Baker, Andrew Day & Guy Ritchie

ShortSummary = The four owners of The Lock, a pub in London's East End, buy a quantity of stolen porn videos and a priceless watch. They think they are in the money but unbeknown to them all the goods were stolen from East London's toughest, hardest gangster, Miami Vice. Not surprisingly he wants his watch back and doesn't care about how he goes about recovering it. The gang have to get the goods back to Miami Vice without him suspecting their involvement, but get caught up in a heap of trouble involving lap dancers, an arsonist, a family of gypsies, and a stolen thoroughbred racehorse.

ShortSummary = A friend of the lads and a 'local businessman', Robbie Rossi, offers them a large sum of money to pick up a delivery of some dodgy designer clothes. Everything goes well until the lads discover that they have been conned and steal the van back for themselves. When they open the van they find it full of Kalshnikov machine guns bought in by Miami Vice to help him out in a turf war. Once more they find themselves on the wrong side of Miami's anger.
Title = ...and a Fistful of Jack and Jills

ShortSummary = The boys are offered a hoard of sex pills on the cheap in return for making a few dodgy deliveries. Everything goes wrong when the pills turn out to be a duff batch and people start dying, and they have just sold a large batch of them to gangland boss, Larry Harmless. To make things even more complicated there are a group of Spaniards, two Dutch druggies and a car full of money floating around.

ShortSummary = The boys accidentally record over a consignment of porn tapes belonging to Deep Throat, a vicious and nasty criminal, while running off copies of a wedding video they made. With just three days to replace or pay for the missing films they use every idea they possibly can to make their own porn videos, so at least they will have something to give to Deep Throat when he comes calling on them.

ShortSummary = Miami Vice is having accountant problems. Not only is someone skimming money from his operations, but Moira is holding out her 10% of Lapland. The boys unwittingly get involved and end up having to pay Miami £20,000 each. Jamie needs to borrow the money from his uncle and has to 'babysit' a friend of his uncle's called 'Two Sips' who is returning to England for a few days.

ShortSummary = Miami Vice goes into the meat business and employs the lads to pick up a consignment being delivered by three psychotic Russians. Moon's country cousins get involved with them and a fight over a prize bull. Meanwhile a drug-crazed duo want their revenge on Miami and intend to get their own hands on the beef to exact it.

ShortSummary = A criminal 'friend' has the key to Miami's safe and he wants it back, but said criminal has been caught by the police and is now in jail. Miami gets Barbie to file some trumped up charges, ensuring that Lee, Bacon and Jamie get sent to the same prison, and tells them that unless they get the key for him he will ensure that the charges will be made to stick.

column1: [[Category:Live action television programs based on films]]","Lock, Stock...","//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lock,_Stock..."
'''Muhammad al-Mukhtar al-Shinqiti''' ([[Arabic]]: '''محمد المختار الشنقيطي'''; born 1966) is a [[Mauritania
column3: political activist]], [[author]], [[scholar]], and academic. He currently works at [[Hamad Bin Khalifa University]] as an [[associate professor]] of [[political ethics]] and [[history of religion]].<ref>{{Cite web
column13: access-date=2020-02-01}}</ref> Besides, he regularly writes Arabic articles in [[Al Jazeera]], which, by now, have exceeded 400 articles.<ref>{{Cite web
column19: title=Dr. Mohamed El-Moctar Shinqiti {{!}} CILE - Research Center for Islamic Legislation and Ethics
column21: access-date=2020-02-01}}</ref> al-Shinqiti has studied and acquired degrees in different fields of both traditional and rational sciences. These include [[Fiqh]], [[Translatology]], [[Business administration]], and [[History of religion]]<ref>{{Cite web
column31: access-date=Feb 1, 2020}}</ref>. He is a strong critic of Arab regimes and writes extensively about the [[Arab Spring

column1: Bearing one of the most common trinomial [[Given name
column2: given names]] in Mauritania, al-Shinqiti was born in Nouakchott to a businessman and scholar. He memorized the [[Quran
column3: Qur'an]] at the age of 11 and expanded his scholarship of religion by taking extra schooling years during high school. Similarly, he then proceeded to take an undergraduate [[Double degree
column4: double major]] in both religious sciences and translation studies.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web
column6: title=El-Moctar is a writer, student and father in addition to serving as a religious leader {{!}} Lubbock Online {{!}} Lubbock Avalanche-Journal

column1: Along with translation in journalism, he first worked as a teacher in secondary schools. Then, due to his perceived conservative background, he was assigned a tutor position in a [[Wahhabism
column2: Wahabi]] university in [[Yemen]]. However, he resigned two years later, stating that his views conflicted with their mainstream ideology, like, for example, denying the religious retribution of [[Apostasy in Islam

column1: During his scholarship in Texas, he volunteered to serve as an [[imam]] in the [[Mosque
column2: Islamic Center]] of [[South Plains]] in [[Lubbock, Texas
column5: title=Ex-Texas Imam Urges Muslims to Join the Gaza Battlefield

column1: Shinqiti is a strong proponent of [[Islamism]] and considers himself \"a brother of [[Muslim Brotherhood
column2: Muslim brotherhood]]\". He emphasizes a compatibility between [[Sharia
column3: Shari'a]] and [[political freedom]], claiming that any purported conflict us a result of an unclear theory of religion. Also, he thinks the Islamic world suffers from a [[schism]] between Islamic and secular factions, which makes inevitable the emphasizing of that compatibility.<ref>{{Cite web
column5: title=Qatar Foundation {{!}} Prominent Islamic Scholar Emphasizes Harmony Between Freedom And Shari’a

column1: During the [[Blockade of the Gaza Strip
column2: Gaza blockade]], he invoked Muslims to join the battlefield and Egyptians to forcefully breach their borders.<ref name=\":1\" /> Also, he has spoken against the Iranian meddling in the middle east, which he thinks was facilitated by the United States.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Arab world worried boosted Iran will further bloody region

column1: In 2008, responding to [[Yahya Jammeh]]'s announcement of his intention to execute all homosexuals<ref name=\"JamehHomosexuality2\">[http://www.gambianow.com/news/News/Gambia-News-President-Jammeh-Gives-Ultimatum-for-Homosexuals-to-.html President Jammeh Gives Ultimatum for Homosexuals to Leave] {{webarchive
column3: date=15 March 2012}}, Gambia News, 19 May 2008.</ref>, al-Shinqiti issued a [[fatwa]] about homosexuality in Islam in which he denied a scriptural ground for punishment of homosexuals. However, he emphasized that it is strongly condemned and is considered by Islam immoral and anti-life.<ref>{{Cite web
column5: title=Threats to Behead Homosexuals: Shari`ah or Politics? - Disciplinary Penalties (ta`zir) - counsels - OnIslam.net
column15: title=Why Gay Marriage May Not Be Contrary To Islam

column1: al-Shinqiti has also expressed a wide support of the [[Turkish involvement in the Syrian Civil War
column2: Turkish involvement in Syria]]. According to him, it is a sign of an Islamic awakening in which \"Arabs and Turks fight against the oppressive regimes\".<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Arab authors, intellectuals extend support to Turkey

column1: al-Shinqiti is married to Oumoul Sidahmed, a former alumni of [[South Plains College]], and they have three children: a son and two daughters. His youngest daughter, Iman, is an American citizen by birth.<ref name=":0" />

column1: <!-- Inline citations added to your article will automatically display here. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WP:REFB for instructions on how to add citations. -->
'''Muhammad al-Mukhtar al-Shinqiti''' ([[Arabic]]: '''محمد المختار الشنقيطي'''; born 1966) is a [[Mauritania
column3: political activist]], [[author]], [[scholar]], and academic. He currently works at [[Hamad Bin Khalifa University]] as an [[associate professor]] of [[political ethics]] and [[history of religion]].<ref>{{Cite web
column13: access-date=2020-02-01}}</ref> Besides, he regularly writes Arabic articles in [[Al Jazeera]], which, by now, have exceeded 400 articles.<ref>{{Cite web
column19: title=Dr. Mohamed El-Moctar Shinqiti {{!}} CILE - Research Center for Islamic Legislation and Ethics
column21: access-date=2020-02-01}}</ref> al-Shinqiti has studied and acquired degrees in different fields of both traditional and rational sciences. These include [[Fiqh]], [[Translatology]], [[Business administration]], and [[History of religion]]<ref>{{Cite web
column31: access-date=Feb 1, 2020}}</ref>. He is a strong critic of Arab regimes and writes extensively about the [[Arab Spring

column1: Bearing one of the most common trinomial [[Given name
column2: given names]] in Mauritania, al-Shinqiti was born in Nouakchott to a businessman and scholar. He memorized the [[Quran
column3: Qur'an]] at the age of 11 and expanded his scholarship of religion by taking extra schooling years during high school. Similarly, he then proceeded to take an undergraduate [[Double degree
column4: double major]] in both religious sciences and translation studies.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web
column6: title=El-Moctar is a writer, student and father in addition to serving as a religious leader {{!}} Lubbock Online {{!}} Lubbock Avalanche-Journal

column1: Along with translation in journalism, he first worked as a teacher in secondary schools. Then, due to his perceived conservative background, he was assigned a tutor position in a [[Wahhabism
column2: Wahabi]] university in [[Yemen]]. However, he resigned two years later, stating that his views conflicted with their mainstream ideology, like, for example, denying the religious retribution of [[Apostasy in Islam

column1: During his scholarship in Texas, he volunteered to serve as an [[imam]] in the [[Mosque
column2: Islamic Center]] of [[South Plains]] in [[Lubbock, Texas
column5: title=Ex-Texas Imam Urges Muslims to Join the Gaza Battlefield

column1: Shinqiti is a strong proponent of [[Islamism]] and considers himself a brother of [[Muslim Brotherhood
column2: Muslim brotherhood]]. He emphasizes a compatibility between [[Sharia
column3: Shari'a]] and [[positive law]], claiming that conflating the two is a result of an unclear theory of religion. Also, he thinks the Islamic world suffers from a [[schism]] between Islamic and secular factions, which makes inevitable the emphasizing of that unity.<ref>{{Cite web
column5: title=Qatar Foundation {{!}} Prominent Islamic Scholar Emphasizes Harmony Between Freedom And Shari’a

column1: During the [[Blockade of the Gaza Strip
column2: Gaza blockade]], he invoked Muslims to join the battlefield and Egyptians to forcefully breach their borders.<ref name=\":1\" /> Also, he has spoken against the Iranian meddling in the middle east, which he thinks was facilitated by the United States.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Arab world worried boosted Iran will further bloody region

column1: In 2008, responding to [[Yahya Jammeh]]'s announcement of his intention to execute all homosexuals<ref name=\"JamehHomosexuality2\">[http://www.gambianow.com/news/News/Gambia-News-President-Jammeh-Gives-Ultimatum-for-Homosexuals-to-.html President Jammeh Gives Ultimatum for Homosexuals to Leave] {{webarchive
column3: date=15 March 2012}}, Gambia News, 19 May 2008.</ref>, al-Shinqiti issued a [[fatwa]] about homosexuality in Islam in which he denied a scriptural ground for punishment of homosexuals. However, he emphasized that it is strongly condemned and is considered by Islam immoral and anti-life.<ref>{{Cite web
column5: title=Threats to Behead Homosexuals: Shari`ah or Politics? - Disciplinary Penalties (ta`zir) - counsels - OnIslam.net
column15: title=Why Gay Marriage May Not Be Contrary To Islam

column1: al-Shinqiti has also expressed a wide support of the [[Turkish involvement in the Syrian Civil War
column2: Turkish involvement in Syria]]. According to him, it is a sign of an Islamic awakening in which \"Arabs and Turks fight against the oppressive regimes\".<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Arab authors, intellectuals extend support to Turkey

column1: al-Shinqiti is married to Oumoul Sidahmed, a former alumni of [[South Plains College]], and they have three children: a son and two daughters. His youngest daughter, Iman, is an American citizen by birth.<ref name=\":0\" />

column4: title=أثر الحروب الصليبية على العلاقات السنية الشيعية
column6: trans-title=The Crusaders' Impact on Suni-Shi'a Relations
column8: publisher=Arab Network for Research and Publishing

column6: trans-title=The Political Disputes Between Companions of the Prophet
column8: publisher=Arab Network for Research and Publishing

column4: title=Hacli Savaslarinin Etkisi Altinda Sunni-Sii Iliskileri
column8: trans-title=The Crusaders' Impact on Suni-Shi'a Relations
trans-title=The Political Disputes Between Companions of the Prophet

column1: <!-- Inline citations added to your article will automatically display here. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WP:REFB for instructions on how to add citations. -->

column2: German]] politician and activist. She has been a member of the [[Bundestag]] since 2017, when she was elected on the party list of [[The Left (Germany)
column3: The Left]], without being a party member. Previously, she was a member of the [[Pirate Party Germany]] and the [[Alliance 90/The Greens
column4: Greens]]. She is married to [[Daniel Domscheit-Berg]].<ref name=\"fr\">{{Cite news

column1: Anke Domscheit-Berg grew up the daughter of an art historian and a doctor in [[Müncheberg]] in the then-[[GDR]].<ref>{{cite news
column8: language=de-DE}}</ref> She has a sister and two brothers.<ref>{{cite web
column14: language=de-DE}}</ref> Domscheit-Berg attended a [[Education in East Germany
column15: polytechnic secondary school]], before transferring to an [[Extended Secondary School (East Germany)
column16: extended secondary school]] in [[Strausberg]] to sit the [[Abitur]] examination.<ref>{{cite web
column19: language=de-DE}}</ref> In 1987 she began studying textile art in [[Schneeberg, Saxony]]. Following German reunification, she worked for three years to finance her further studies. In 1993 she began studying [[business economics]] at the [[accadis Hochschule Bad Homburg
column20: International Business School]] in [[Bad Homburg vor der Höhe]], specialising in political economy and international economic relationships as well as the [[Spanish language]]. In 1996 she gained a ''[[Bachelor of Arts]] - International Business Administration'' degree and in the same year completed a [[Master of Business Administration]] degree at [[Northumbria University]].<ref>{{cite web

column1: After graduating she worked as a management consultant at [[Accenture]] and [[McKinsey]]. From 2008 to 2011, Domscheit-Berg was active as a lobbyist for [[Microsoft]] in Germany. Following that, she was self-employed as a writer and businesswoman.<ref>{{cite web
column7: language=de-DE}}</ref> In 2016 she founded [[ViaEuropa]] together with [[Daniel Domscheit-Berg]] and [[Jonas Birgersson]]. The company aims to promote the decentralised development of fibre-optic networks in Germany. In 2017, she stepped down from the position of managing director.{{cn}}

column1: In 2010 she was an honorary supervisory board member of [[Teach First Deutschland]].{{cn}} She was a freelance policy advisor at the [[World Future Council]] on the topic of violence against women and girls and an honorary member of the think-tank of the German NGO [[Welthungerhilfe]].<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Die Gefahr westlicher Überlegenheitsphantasien - Amelie Fried berichtet aus Äthiopien
column9: title=Einladung: Geflüchtete Kinder und Frauen Schützen
column13: language=de}}</ref> In 2015 she was a member of the jury for the {{ill

column1: From June-October 2017 she worked part-time as a research assistant to [[Petra Sitte]], a member of the German [[Bundestag]].<ref>{{cite web
In 2000, Domscheit-Berg gave birth to a son. After separating from the father, she was a single mother for a while.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Die alleinerziehende Mutter ist ein Auslaufmodell. Auch wenn ihr das selbst vielleicht nicht bewusst ist. Und den Vätern erst recht nicht: Niemand allein

column1: Anke Domscheit-Berg was a member of [[Alliance 90/The Greens]] in the [[Mitte]] borough of [[Berlin]].<ref>{{cite web
column6: language=de}}</ref> In May 2012 she joined the [[Pirate Party Germany]].<ref>{{cite news
column7: title=Anke Domscheit-Berg wechselt zu den Piraten
column10: language=de}}</ref> From August 2013 to July 2014, Domscheit-Berg was chair of the Pirate Party in [[Brandenburg]].<ref>{{cite news

column1: In the [[2013 German federal election]], Domscheit-Berg was second on the Pirates' party list in Brandenburg, and also stood as a direct candidate in the single-member constituency of [[Oberhavel – Havelland II]].<ref>{{cite news
column2: title=Piraten: Netzaktivistin Domscheit-Berg nur auf Listenplatz zwei
column7: language=de}}</ref> In the [[2014 European Parliament election]], she was third on the Pirate Party's national party list.<ref>{{cite news
column8: title=Piratenpartei: Parteitag in Bochum zur Europawahl
column12: language=de}}</ref> She was however unsuccessful in both elections.

column1: In September 2014, Domscheit-Berg left the Pirate Party.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Der letzte Tropfen war zu viel. Tschüss, Piratenpartei. (archived)
column9: language=de}}</ref> In the [[2017 German federal election]], she stood as a candidate for [[The Left (Germany)
column10: The Left]] in the constituency of [[Brandenburg an der Havel – Potsdam-Mittelmark I – Havelland III – Teltow-Fläming I]], without being a party member, as well as taking third place on the party list of [[The Left (Germany)
column16: language=de}}</ref> She was defeated in the consituency by [[Christian Democratic Union of Germany
column17: CDU]] candidate [[Dietlind Tiemann]], but was elected as a member of the Bundestag via the party list. She is the chair of the Left group in the Bundestag's 'Digital Agenda' committee.<ref>{{cite web
column20: title=Wer sitzt im Ausschuss Digitale Agenda?

column3: Mauern einreißen! Weil ich glaube, dass wir die Welt verändern können.}}'' (Break down walls! Because I believe we can change the world.) Heyne Verlag, Munich 2014, {{ISBN

column3: caption=First [[tone row]] of the third movement of Webern's Variations for piano, Op. 27.<ref>Bailey 1991, 24; Wason 1987, 74.</ref> {{audio

column1: '''Variations for piano''', Op. 27, is a [[twelve-tone technique
column3: piece]] for [[piano]] composed by [[Anton Webern]] in 1936. It consists of three movements:

column1: Webern's only published work for solo piano, the Variations are one of his major instrumental works and a signal example of his late style.<ref name=\"Bailey 1998, 151\">Bailey 1998, 151.</ref> Webern dedicated the work to pianist [[Eduard Steuermann]].<ref>Webern 1937: \"Eduard Steuemann / gewidmet\" (on frontispiece).</ref> However, it was premiered (after months of coaching from Webern) by [[Peter Stadlen]] on 26 October 1937 in Vienna.<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=0eYMDtLL4X4C&pg=PA152&dq=Webern+26+October&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjh2Jange_nAhVXTxUIHUjKCJgQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=Webern%2026%20October&f=false] Bailey 1998 p 152</ref> Much later Stadlen produced the definitive interpretive edition of Op.27, published by [[Universal Edition]] in 1979.<ref>''Notes''(2nd Series), Vol 27 No 2, December 190, p 405-406</ref>
By the early 1930s Webern was one of the composers and artists criticised by the [[Nazi Party]], which was rapidly gaining power. By 1934 Webern's [[Conductor (music)
column2: conducting]] career, a major source of income for the composer, was practically over, and he earned his living by teaching composition to a few private pupils. Despite the considerable disadvantages this financial situation had, the lack of a stable job provided Webern with more time to compose.<ref name=\"Bailey 1998, 151\"/>

column1: Opus 27 took Webern about a year to complete. The three movements were not composed in the order they appear in the work:<ref>Dates from: Bailey 1991, 452.</ref>
* Third movement: begun 14 October 1935, completed 8 July 1936
* First movement: begun 22 July 1936, completed 19 August 1936
* Second movement: begun 25 August 1936, completed 5 November 1936

The piece is the only work for piano solo that was published by the composer and assigned an opus number. It was also the last work by Webern to be published by [[Universal Edition]] during his lifetime.<ref>Bailey 1998, 152.</ref>
All three movements of the work are 12-tone pieces based on the following row (as found at the beginning of the second movement<ref name=\"Nolan\"/>):

column5: Principal forms of Webern's tone row from Variations for piano, op. 27, movement 2.<ref name=\"Nolan\">Nolan 1995, 49–50, though her 0 is G{{Music
column6: sharp}}, and so she labels these two row forms P8 and I10.</ref> The first simultaneous pairing of row forms is P1 and R8, and as with the principal forms, each hexachord fills in a chromatic fourth, with B as the pivot (end of P1 and beginning of IR8), and thus linked by the prominent tritone in the center of the row {{audio
column7: Webern - Piano Variations op. 27 tone row.mid

column1: The work's title, ''Variations'', is ambiguous. In a letter dated 18 July, Webern wrote: \"The completed part is a variations movement; the whole will be a kind of 'Suite'\".<ref>Bailey 1991, 189.</ref> Only the third movement was completed at the time, and it is clearly [[Variation (music)
column2: a set of variations]]. The form of the other two movements conforms to the \"[[Suite (music)
column3: Suite]]\" plan: the first movement is a [[ternary form]], ABA, and the second is a [[binary form]]. However, to refer to an entire work by the form of its last movement is very unusual, and numerous attempts have been made to explain the title.<ref>Bailey 1991, 189–190.</ref>

column1: Webern scholar Kathryn Bailey outlined three possible views on the structure of the piece. Webern's Variations may be considered any of these:<ref name=\"Bailey 1991, 190\">Bailey 1991, 190.</ref>
# A three-movement sonata: [[sonata form]] – binary [[scherzo]] – variations
# A three-movement suite: ternary movement – binary movement – variations
# A set of variations, in which the first two movements have little connection to the third

One of the earliest explanations was offered by [[René Leibowitz]], who in 1948 described the first movement as a theme and two variations, the second movement as a theme with a single variation, and the third movement as five variations of yet another theme.<ref name=\"Bailey 1991, 190\"/> Willi Reich, a member of [[Arnold Schoenberg]]'s circle, described the work as a sonatina which begins with a set of variations (first movement) and ends with a sonata form (third movement). Reich claimed his explanation was identical to Webern's and stemmed from the two men's conversations, however, the authenticity of this claim has been questioned.<ref>Bailey 1991, 191.</ref>

Yet another explanation was provided by Friedhelm Dōhl (who published Reich's analysis, but did not find it satisfactory), who viewed each of the fourteen phrases in the first movement as a variation of the prime/retrograde idea, and found the same structure in the second movement. Robert U. Nelson published a similar analysis in 1969.<ref>Nelson 1969.</ref> Finally, Kathryn Bailey's analysis suggests that the first movement is a sonata form, her ideas supported by Webern's own remarks in the original manuscript, published in 1979 by Peter Stadlen.<ref name=\"Bailey 1991, 192\">Bailey 1991, 192.</ref>

A particularly notable feature of Variations is [[symmetry]], which is featured throughout the work. Horizontal symmetry can be observed, for example, in successive phrases of the first movement: bars 1–18 comprise four phrases, each built from the normal row and its retrograde stated simultaneously, and the second half of the phrase is always a reverse of the first. Each phrase is therefore a [[palindrome]], though only the first pair of rows in the beginning of the movement is perfectly palindromic.<ref name=\"Bailey 1991, 192\"/> Vertical symmetry pervades the second movement, which is a [[Canon (music)
column2: canon]]. The pitches are arranged around the pitch axis of A4. Each downward reaching interval is replicated exactly in the opposite direction.<ref>Bailey 1991, 262–264.</ref>
