The piece is the only work for piano solo that was published by the composer and assigned an opus number. It was also the last work by Webern to be published by [[Universal Edition]] during his lifetime.<ref>Bailey 1998, 152.</ref>
All three movements of the work are 12-tone pieces based on the following row (as found at the beginning of the second movement<ref name=\"Nolan\"/>):

column5: Principal forms of Webern's tone row from Variations for piano, op. 27, movement 2.<ref name=\"Nolan\">Nolan 1995, 49–50, though her 0 is G{{Music
column6: sharp}}, and so she labels these two row forms P8 and I10.</ref> The first simultaneous pairing of row forms is P1 and R8, and as with the principal forms, each hexachord fills in a chromatic fourth, with B as the pivot (end of P1 and beginning of IR8), and thus linked by the prominent tritone in the center of the row {{audio
column7: Webern - Piano Variations op. 27 tone row.mid

column1: The work's title, ''Variations'', is ambiguous. In a letter dated 18 July, Webern wrote: \"The completed part is a variations movement; the whole will be a kind of 'Suite'\".<ref>Bailey 1991, 189.</ref> Only the third movement was completed at the time, and it is clearly [[Variation (music)
column2: a set of variations]]. The form of the other two movements conforms to the \"[[Suite (music)
column3: Suite]]\" plan: the first movement is a [[ternary form]], ABA, and the second is a [[binary form]]. However, to refer to an entire work by the form of its last movement is very unusual, and numerous attempts have been made to explain the title.<ref>Bailey 1991, 189–190.</ref>

column1: Webern scholar Kathryn Bailey outlined three possible views on the structure of the piece. Webern's Variations may be considered any of these:<ref name=\"Bailey 1991, 190\">Bailey 1991, 190.</ref>
# A three-movement sonata: [[sonata form]] – binary [[scherzo]] – variations
# A three-movement suite: ternary movement – binary movement – variations
# A set of variations, in which the first two movements have little connection to the third

One of the earliest explanations was offered by [[René Leibowitz]], who in 1948 described the first movement as a theme and two variations, the second movement as a theme with a single variation, and the third movement as five variations of yet another theme.<ref name=\"Bailey 1991, 190\"/> Willi Reich, a member of [[Arnold Schoenberg]]'s circle, described the work as a sonatina which begins with a set of variations (first movement) and ends with a sonata form (third movement). Reich claimed his explanation was identical to Webern's and stemmed from the two men's conversations, however, the authenticity of this claim has been questioned.<ref>Bailey 1991, 191.</ref>

Yet another explanation was provided by Friedhelm Dōhl (who published Reich's analysis, but did not find it satisfactory), who viewed each of the fourteen phrases in the first movement as a variation of the prime/retrograde idea, and found the same structure in the second movement. Robert U. Nelson published a similar analysis in 1969.<ref>Nelson 1969.</ref> Finally, Kathryn Bailey's analysis suggests that the first movement is a sonata form, her ideas supported by Webern's own remarks in the original manuscript, published in 1979 by Peter Stadlen.<ref name=\"Bailey 1991, 192\">Bailey 1991, 192.</ref>

A particularly notable feature of Variations is [[symmetry]], which is featured throughout the work. Horizontal symmetry can be observed, for example, in successive phrases of the first movement: bars 1–18 comprise four phrases, each built from the normal row and its retrograde stated simultaneously, and the second half of the phrase is always a reverse of the first. Each phrase is therefore a [[palindrome]], though only the first pair of rows in the beginning of the movement is perfectly palindromic.<ref name=\"Bailey 1991, 192\"/> Vertical symmetry pervades the second movement, which is a [[Canon (music)
column2: canon]]. The pitches are arranged around the pitch axis of A4. Each downward reaching interval is replicated exactly in the opposite direction.<ref>Bailey 1991, 262–264.</ref>

column2: Canadian]] [[composer]] and [[guitarist]]. He is currently a [[Professor]] of [[Musical composition

column7: last=Memorial University of Newfoundland School of Music

column1: Composer Andrew Staniland was born in [[Red Deer, Alberta
column2: Red Deer]], [[Alberta]], in 1977. His first instrument was the [[guitar]], and he began playing in [[Heavy metal music
column3: heavy-metal]] bands as a young teen. Staniland began formal studies in jazz and arranging at Grant MacEwan Community College in Edmonton (now [[MacEwan University]]), where he also studied composition with Gordon Nicholson. He then studied [[classical guitar]] at the [[University of Lethbridge]], Alberta, before obtaining both a [[Master's degree
column4: Master's]] and [[Doctorate]] degree in Composition from the [[University of Toronto]].<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web
column6: title=Andrew Staniland accelerates toward the next idea

column1: A composer whose work has been performed and broadcast in over 35 countries,<ref name=\":3\" /> Staniland has been commissioned by musicians and ensembles such as cellist [[Frances-Marie Uitti]], Duo Concertante (violinist [[Nancy Dahn]] and pianist Timothy Steeves), the [[Gryphon Trio]], and [[Les Percussions de Strasbourg]]. He has also been an Affiliate Composer with both the [[National Arts Centre Orchestra]] (2002-2004) and the [[Toronto Symphony Orchestra]] (2006-2009), and in 2005 was a [[Artist-in-residence
column3: Centre de Création Musicale Iannis Xenakis]] in Paris.<ref name=\":12\">{{Cite web

column1: In 2010 Staniland joined the faculty of the [[Music school
column2: School of Music]] at Memorial University of Newfoundland,<ref name=\":0\" /> where he teaches composition and electronic music. There Staniland founded the Memorial ElectroAcoustic Research Lab (MEARL),<ref name=\":2\" /> where he is part of a cross-disciplinary research team that has created the Mune, an electronic music performance instrument that \"combines the functionality of a [[MIDI controller]] ... with the expressiveness and simplicity of an acoustic instrument.\"<ref>{{Cite web

column1: Staniland is an Associate Composer of the [[Canadian Music Centre]],<ref name=\":3\">{{Cite web
column4: last=Canadian Music Centre {{!}} Centre de Musique Canadienne
column12: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref> a member of the [[Canadian League of Composers]],<ref>{{Cite web
column14: title=Current Members {{!}} Canadian League of Composers
column16: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref> and an inaugural member of the College of New Scholars, Artists and Scientists of the [[Royal Society of Canada]].<ref name=\":2\" />

column1: Staniland has been the recipient of many prestigious awards, including a 2018 [[East Coast Music Association
column2: ECMA]] Award for Classical Composition of the Year (for ''The River is Within Us''),<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=ECMA 2018 Wrap-Up: View The Full List Of Winners! - East Coast Music Association
column6: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref> the 2016 Terra Nova Young Innovator Award,<ref>{{Cite web
column17: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref> the National Grand Prize of EVOLUTION (presented in 2009 by [[CBC Music
column19: Espace Musique]] and [[The Banff Centre]]), and the 2004 Karen Keiser Prize in Canadian Music.<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite web
column24: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref> He has also received three [[Juno Award

column1: *''The Ocean is Full of its Own Collapse'' (2015) for narrator, piano and violin (based on [[Lisa Moore (writer)
*''Choro: “The Joyful Lament for Villa Lobos”'' (2014) for 2 guitars
*''Orion Constellation Theory'' (2014) Version 2, arranged for two snare drums

*''At the Laurentian Room'' (2008) for soprano and piano

*''Peter Quince at the Clavier'' (2008) for baritone and piano
*''Road to Berlin'' (2008) for bass and piano
*''Ashlike on the Cradle of the Wind'' (2005) chamber opera (Libretto by Jill Battson)
*''Reflections on O Canada after Truth and Reconciliation'' (2016)
*''(RE)VOLUTION'' (2011) Concerto for electric guitar and orchestra
*''Only Darkness'' (2010) for orchestra and mezzo soprano
*''Variations on a Theme by D.H Lawrence'' (2001) for piano and string orchestra
*''Four Horsemen'' (2012) for symphonic band and electronics

column1: '''cmd.exe''' is the default [[command-line interpreter]] for [[OS/2]], [[eComStation]], [[Windows]], [[Windows CE]], and the [[ReactOS]] operating systems.  The name refers to its executable filename.  It is also commonly referred to as '''cmd''' or the '''Command Prompt''', referring to the default window title on Windows.  The implementations differ on the various systems but the behavior and basic set of commands is generally consistent.  {{mono
column3: [[COMMAND.COM]]}} in [[DOS]] and [[Windows 9x]] systems, and analogous to the [[Unix shell]]s used on [[Unix-like]] systems. The initial version of {{mono
column4: cmd.exe}} for Windows NT was developed by Therese Stowell.<ref name=\"Zachary_1994\"/> On [[Windows CE .NET 4.2]],<ref>[https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/previous-versions/windows/embedded/ms879823(v%3dmsdn.10) Command Processor Shell (Windows CE .NET 4.2)
column5: Microsoft Docs]</ref> [[Windows CE 5.0]]<ref>[https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/previous-versions/windows/embedded/aa453925%28v%3dmsdn.10%29 Command Processor Shell (Windows CE 5.0)
column6: Microsoft Docs]</ref> and [[Windows Embedded CE 6.0]]<ref>[https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/previous-versions/windows/embedded/ee499728%28v%3dwinembedded.60%29 Command Processor Shell (Windows Embedded CE 6.0)
column7: Microsoft Docs]</ref> it is also referred to as '''Command Processor Shell'''.

column2: cmd.exe}} interacts with the user through a [[command-line interface]]. On Windows, this interface is implemented through the [[Win32 console]]. {{mono
column3: cmd.exe}} may take advantage of features available to native programs of its own platform. For example, on OS/2 and Windows, it can use real [[Pipeline (Unix)
column4: pipes]] in command pipelines, allowing both sides of the pipeline to run concurrently. As a result, it is possible to redirect the [[standard error stream]]. ({{mono
column5: COMMAND.COM}} uses temporary files, and runs the two sides serially, one after the other.)

column4: cmd.exe}} on [[Windows NT]] and later:<ref>{{Cite book

column1: The following list of commands is supported by {{mono
column8: website=docs.microsoft.com}}</ref> and Windows Embedded CE 6.0.<ref>{{Cite web

column3: COMMAND.COM}} but provides the following extensions over it:

column1: * More detailed error messages than the blanket \"[[Bad command or file name]]\" (in the case of malformed commands) of {{mono
column2: COMMAND.COM}}. In OS/2, errors are reported in the chosen language of the system, their text being taken from the system message files. The {{mono
column4: HELP]]}} command can then be issued with the error message number to obtain further information.

column1: * Supports using of arrow keys to scroll through command history. (Under DOS this function was only available under [[DR DOS]] (through [[HISTORY (CONFIG.SYS directive)
column2: HISTORY]]) and later via a external component called {{mono

column1: * Adds [[command-line completion]] for file and folder paths.

column2: ^}}) as the [[escape character]]; the character following it is to be taken literally. There are special characters in {{mono
column7: \") that are meant to alter the behavior of the command line processor. The caret character forces the command line processor to interpret them literally.

column1: * Supports delayed variable expansion with [[SETLOCAL EnableDelayedExpansion]], allowing values of variables to be calculated at runtime instead of during parsing of script before execution (Windows 2000 and later), fixing DOS idioms that made using [[control structures]] hard and complex.<ref name=\"Delay\"/> The extensions can be disabled, providing a stricter compatibility mode.
Internal commands have also been improved:

column4: RD]]}} command, as part of its {{mono

column3: EndLocal}} commands limit the scope of changes to the environment. Changes made to the command line environment after {{mono
column4: SetLocal}} commands are local to the [[batch file]]. {{mono
column5: EndLocal}} command restores the previous settings.<ref name=\"SetLocal\"/>

column2: Call}} command allows subroutines within batch file. The {{mono
column4: COMMAND.COM}} only supports calling external batch files.

column1: * File name parser extensions to the {{mono
column2: Set}} command are comparable with [[C shell]].{{Elucidate

column3: For]]}} command supports parsing files and arbitrary sets in addition to file names.

column5: PopD]]}} commands provide access past navigated paths similar to \"forward\" and \"back\" buttons in a web browser or [[File Explorer]].

column3: case-insensitive]] comparisons and numeric equality and inequality comparisons in addition to case-sensitive string comparisons. (This was available in DR-DOS, but not in [[PC DOS]] or [[MS-DOS]].)

Internal commands have also been improved:

column4: RD]]}} command, as part of its {{mono

column3: EndLocal}} commands limit the scope of changes to the environment. Changes made to the command line environment after {{mono
column4: SetLocal}} commands are local to the [[batch file]]. {{mono
column5: EndLocal}} command restores the previous settings.<ref name=\"SetLocal\"/>

column2: Call}} command allows subroutines within batch file. The {{mono
column4: COMMAND.COM}} only supports calling external batch files.

column1: * File name parser extensions to the {{mono
column2: Set}} command are comparable with [[C shell]].{{Elucidate

column3: For]]}} command supports parsing files and arbitrary sets in addition to file names.

column5: PopD]]}} commands provide access past navigated paths similar to \"forward\" and \"back\" buttons in a web browser or [[File Explorer]].

column3: case-insensitive]] comparisons and numeric equality and inequality comparisons in addition to case-sensitive string comparisons. (This was available in DR-DOS, but not in [[PC DOS]] or [[MS-DOS]].)

column4: title=Covid-19 stats at a glance as of 10.04.2020#Covid19Tanzania#Covid19TZ#COVID19TZA #coronavirusTanzaniapic.twitter.com/QIXmFl4IzE

column1: The [[2019–20 coronavirus pandemic]] was confirmed to have reached [[Tanzania]] in March 2020.
{{2019–20 coronavirus pandemic data/Tanzania medical cases chart}}

On 12 January 2020, the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) confirmed that a [[novel coronavirus]] was the cause of a respiratory illness in a cluster of people in Wuhan City, Hubei Province, China, which was reported to the WHO on 31 December 2019.<ref name=Elsevier>{{cite web
column14: title=What is coronavirus and how close is it to becoming a pandemic?

column2: case fatality ratio]] for COVID-19 has been much lower than [[Severe acute respiratory syndrome
column12: title=High consequence infectious diseases (HCID); Guidance and information about high consequence infectious diseases and their management in England
column22: transmission]] has been significantly greater, with a significant total death toll.<ref name=WFSA>{{cite web
column24: title=World Federation Of Societies of Anaesthesiologists – Coronavirus

column1: On 16 March, the first case in Tanzania was confirmed in [[Arusha]].<ref name=\"WOMC\">{{cite web
column8: title=Somalia, Tanzania confirm first coronavirus cases
column12: url-status=live}}</ref> It was a 46-year-old Tanzanian who had come to Arusha from [[Belgium]].<ref>{{Cite web

column1: On 17 March, the Prime Minister announced a range of measures, including closing schools.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Tanzania bans all public gathering, closes schools, suspends the Premier League over Coronavirus

column1: On 18 March, two other cases in Tanzania were reported.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Coronavirus cases rise to three in Tanzania

column1: On 19 March two new cases were reported, bringing the total to six. Five cases were located in capital city of [[Dar es Salaam]] with the other in [[Zanzibar]].<ref>

column3: title=COVID-19: Tanzania traces 112 contacts as cases rise to six

column1: On 22 March, it was announced that cases had risen to 12.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Covid-19 cases in Tanzania now rise to 12, says President

column1: On 23 March, the Government announced that all incoming travelers from COVID affected countries would be placed in quarantine at their own cost for 14 days.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=23.03.2020 - Update on COVID-19 in Tanzania

column1: On 25 March, it was announced that Zanzibar recorded its second case.<ref>{{Cite web
On 26 March, the first COVID recovery was announced, of the first Arusha patient.<ref>{{Cite web
On 28 March, a third case was recorded in Zanzibar.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Zanzibar health minister confirms third covid-19 case

column1: On 30 March, there were 5 more recorded cases, 2 in Zanzibar and 3 in mainland Tanzania, bringing the cumulative total to 19.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=VIDEO: Covid-19 cases in Tanzania rise to 19 as five more cases

column1: On 31 March, the first COVID death was recorded, in Dar es Salaam.<ref>{{Cite web
On 1 April, 1 new case and 1 recovery in Dar es Salaam was announced, bringing the cumulative totals to 20 cases, 2 recoveries and 1 death.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Second Tanzanian patient recovers from coronavirus

column1: On 3 April, a  third recovery in Kagera was announced, bringing the active case number to 16.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=COVID-19 Response: US gives 2.3bn/-, patient recovers

column1: On 5 April, 2 new cases were reported in Zanzibar.
On 6 April, a  further 2 new cases were reported in Dar es Salaam and Mwanza, bringing the cumulative total to 24.<ref>{{Cite web
On 7 April, 2 more cases recovered, bringing total recoveries to 5.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Tanzania records two more Covid-19 recoveries

column1: On 8 April, 1 new case was recorded.

On 10 April, it was announced that there were 5 new cases on mainland, 2 new cases on Zanzibar, and 2 deaths on the mainland, bringing the cumulative case count to 32, and cumulative deaths to 3.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Tanzania records two more deaths as Covid-19 cases rise to 32

column1: On 13 April, 14 new cases were reported, 13 in Dar es Salaam and 1 in Arusha.<ref>{{Cite web

The '''Ornate Butterflyfish''', '''Chaetodon ornatissimus''', is a [[species]] of butterflyfish in the [[family]] ''Chaetodontidae'' and [[genus]] ''Chaetodon''. ''Chaetodon'' is a tropical fish genus which contains 87 species <ref name=\":0\">Froese, R. and D. Pauly. Editors. 2019. FishBase. World Wide Web electronic publication. www.fishbase.org, (2019)</ref>. ''Chaetodon'' is the largest genus in the family ''Chaetodontidae'' <ref name=\":0\" />.

''C. ornatissimus'' is commonly referred to as:  Clown Butterflyfish, Clown Butterfly, Coralfishes, Ornate Butterfly, Ornate Coralfish and Ornatissimus Butterfly. The Ornate Butterflyfish is a close relative of the [[Mailed butterflyfish
column2: Mailed Butterflyfish]] (''C. reticulatus'') and the [[Scrawled butterflyfish
column3: Scrawled Butterflyfish]] (''C. meyeri'') <ref name=\":1\">Fessler, Jennifer L., and Mark W. Westneat. \"Molecular phylogenetics of the butterflyfishes (Chaetodontidae): taxonomy and biogeography of a global coral reef fish family.\" ''Molecular phylogenetics and evolution'' 45.1 (2007): 50-68.</ref>. Together they make up the subgenus called “Citharoedus”, but as this name had already been used for the mollusk genus when it was given to the fish, it is not valid. They are probably quite close to the subgenus Corallochaetodon, which contains the [[Melon butterflyfish
column4: Melon Butterflyfish]] (''C. trifasciatus''). Like these, they might be separated into Megaprotodon if the [[genus]] ''[[Chaetodon]]'' is split up <ref name=\":1\" />.

column1: ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' is most easily identified by its color pattern which helps protect them from predators. Ornate butterflyfish have white bodies with orange to orange-brown oblique bands <ref name=\":0\" />. They also have two yellow-edged black bars on their head: one runs across the eyes and the other is on the snout, and the tail has two black bars <ref name=\":0\" />. The size of the ornate butterflyfish ranges from 13-18 cm total length (mean +/- SD = 16.2 +/- 1.4 cm) and pair members are nearly always indistinguishable based on size <ref name=\":3\">Adam, T. C. (2010). Competition encourages cooperation: client fish receive higher-quality service when cleaner fish compete. ''Animal Behaviour'', ''79''(6), 1183-1189.</ref>.
''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' adults are predominately found in pairs that occupy exclusive territories including Clearwater [[Lagoon
column2: lagoons]] and seaward reefs rich in coral growth (size range ~100-1400m2) <ref name=\":3\" />. On the other hand, juvenile ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'' live in solitary, tend to be shy, and live in the arms of branching corals for protection <ref name=\":0\" />. Once juveniles reach breeding age, they form pairs <ref name=\":0\" />. It is uncommon to find adult ''Chaetodon ornatissimus'''  without a mate. Pairs also establish a \"home range\" where you will likely always find them <ref name=\":0\" />.

column1: The Ornate Butterflyfish is widespread throughout the [[Tropics
column2: tropical]] waters of the Indo-Pacific area ranging from [[Sri Lanka]] to [[Hawaii]], the [[Marquesas Islands
column3: Marquesas]], the [[Pitcairn Islands]], North to Southern [[Japan]], South to Lord Howe, and Rapa in the Austral Islands <ref>Hernández, Sebastián, et al. \"First Records of Striped Boarfish Evistias acutirostris and Ornate Butterflyfish Chaetodon ornatissimus from Easter Island1.\" ''Pacific Science'' 69.4 (2015): 525-529.</ref>. Over three-quraters of the world's fish species inhabit this region<ref>{{aut
column4: Hsu, Kui-Ching; Chen, Jeng-Ping & Shao, Kwang-Tsao}}(2007): Molecular phylogeny of ''Chaetodon''(Teleostei: Chaetodontidae) in the Indo-West Pacific: evolution in geminate species pairs and species groups. ''Raffles Bulletin of Zoology Supplement'''''14''': 77–86.</ref>. The environment ''C. ornatissimus'' lives in is marine, inshore, tropical (30°N - 30°S, 77°E - 124°W) and reef associated <ref name=\":2\">Myers, R. F. (1991). ''Micronesian reef fishes''. Barrigada, Guam: Coral Graphics.</ref>. They tend to live at a depth range between 1-36 meters <ref name=\":2\" />.

column1: There are many natural and anthropogenic disruptions which play a major role in loss of habitat of organisms living in coral reef communities. Sessile, benthic communities on tropical coral reefs have natural disruptions including tropical storms, unseasonal temperature extremes and infestations of crown-of-thorn sea stars (''Acanthaster planci'')<ref name=\":5\">Pratchett, M. S., Wilson, S. K., & Baird, A. H. (2006). Declines in the abundance of Chaetodon butterflyfishes following extensive coral depletion. ''Journal of fish Biology'', ''69''(5), 1269-1280.</ref>. These events are becoming more frequent which makes anthropogenic influences more chronic. Anthropogenic disturbances include overfishing, pollution and coastal development all of which cause depletion in corals<ref name=\":5\" />. Over 30 percent of the coral reef communities in the world have already been degraded; however, by 2030 more than 60 percent of coral reef communities will have been lost<ref name=\":5\" />.

These changes in the structure of benthic coral reef habitats have adverse effects on coral reef fish, specifically butterflyfish. Several studies documented the decline of butterflyfish, and localized extinctions, following coral depletion. A study by Pratchett et. al., revealed declines in abundance of ''Chaetodon'' butterflyfish were almost certainly related to coral depletion<ref name=\":5\" />. Declines in abundances of butterflyfish were due to starvation<ref name=\":5\" />.

Another adverse anthropogenic effect which alters habitat community composition is the shift from coral-dominated to seaweed-dominated benthic communities. Anthropogenic impacts of overfishing of herbivorous fish and increase of eutrophication create favorable conditions for seaweed growthBrooker, R. M. ''et al.'' Cryptic effects of habitat declines: coral-associated fishes avoid coral-seaweed interactions due to visual and chemical cues. ''Sci. Rep.'' '''6''', 18842; doi: 10.1038/srep18842 (2016).. Increase in seaweed-dominated benthic communities’ limits expansion of coral colonies and availability of surfaces for larval settlement and development. Coral reef communities provide shelter, and food resources for Butterflyfish. However, the presence of seaweed has a substantial impact on butterflyfish, as they actively avoid corals in contact with seaweed.

''C. ornatissimus'' feed exclusively on coral polyp tissue and small organisms. Butterflyfish feed on ten different coral species, which is the broadest range of corals when compared with other coral-eating  butterflyfish species <ref name=\":4\">Collinske, G. (2017, August 2). Awesome Fish Spotlight: The Ornate Butterflyfish: Reef Builders: The Reef and Saltwater Aquarium Blog. Retrieved from <nowiki>https://reefbuilders.com/2017/08/02/awesome-fish-spotlight-the-ornate-butterflyfish/</nowiki></ref>. Other obligate corallivores (coral-eating) butterflyfish species include: ''[[Blacktail butterflyfish
column15: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref>''.'' Butterflyfish are obligate corallivores, which means the majority of their diet must be made up of live coral polyp - coral mucous rather than coral tissue<ref name=\":4\" />. Butterflyfish have very fine hair-like teeth that enable them to pick out small organisms inaccessible to most other fish for eating <ref name=\":0\" />. They thrive mainly on a diet of [[Polyp (zoology)
column18: Christmas-tree worms]]. All of those food sources tend to crawl back into their shells; therefore, butterflyfish need to be able to hover motionless while picking at the coral, and to dart swiftly over short distances to get the organisms that retreat into hiding before they retract <ref name=\":0\" />. Ornate Butterflyfish are able to do this by using their pectoral fins as oars to brake, sprint, turn and reverse <ref name=\":0\" />.

column1: '''Camarero''' (1951–1956) was a [[Thoroughbred]] racehorse that was raised and raced in [[Puerto Rico]]. He was the winner of 73 races, including the [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing]] in Puerto Rico. Camarero is notable for setting the current world record of the most [[Winning streak (sports)
column2: consecutive wins]] for a [[Thoroughbred]] racehorse at 56 in a series of races between April 1953 and August 1955.

column1: Cameraro was sired by Thirteen who was a son of 1938 Travers Stakes winner Thanksgiving. His name translates to \"waiter\" in Spanish. Camarero was a small bay colt that weighed 750 pounds and stood only 14 hands high. His male line traced to [[The Finn]] and he was bred and owned by prominent [[San Juan, Puerto Rico
column2: San Juan]] newspaper man Jose Coll-Vidal.<ref name= \"ny55\">New York Times. Aug 9, 1955</ref>

column1: As per Puerto Rican racetrack regulation, [[Parimutuel betting
column2: prohibitive]] favorites are not allowed to be wagered on, which meant that for most of Camarero's winning streak no on-track bets were taken.<ref name=\"ny55\"/> Camarero was the first winner of Puerto Rico's [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing]], winning the Governor's Cup, Jose de Diego Stakes and Primavera Stakes in 1954, undefeated.<ref>[http://www.thoroughbredtimes.com/weekly-feature-articles/2005/August/05/Camareros-record-of-56-consecutive-wins-turns-50.aspx Thoroughbred Times. Aug. 5, 2005]</ref><ref>Jorge Colón Delgado. ''Camarero en punta.'' 1998.</ref> As well according to Hall of Fame Jockey Angel Cordero Jr \"he[Cameraro] means horse racing.\"

column1: On July 19, 1951, Camarera foaled a black colt with four white pasterns who was named Sabrosito. Through Coll-Vidal's foal-sharing agreement with breeder Luis Rechani-Agrait, the colt was bred in Rechani-Agrait's name and foaled on his farm.

A year later, Coll-Vidal and trainer Pablo Suarez first saw Sabrosito, whom Coll-Vidal said looked like a small donkey. However, Suarez insisted that Coll-Vidal take the well-bred yearling. He did and renamed the colt Camarero in honor of his dam.
At the beginning of the 1950s, Puerto Rico's economy had declined and many lived in poverty. By 1953, when Camarero began his career, only two tracks were operating.

Camarero made his first start on April 14, 1953, at two furlongs at Quintana racetrack and won by three lengths. On May 17, he won his second race; seven days later, he won his first stakes race in front-running fashion by four lengths. On July 17, he won his fifth race when he took the six-furlong Luis Mu-oz Rivera Stakes by seven lengths. From August 23 to October 23, Camarero won eight more races, including another stakes. His jockey in his first 13 victories was Juan Diaz-Andino.

Coll-Vidal had come close to Kincsem's record with two other horses, Cofresi and Condado, who won 49 and 44 consecutive races, respectively. He believed that for Camarero to break the record, he would have to replace the colt's jockey with leading rider Mateo Matos.

In 1952, Matos exercised horses at Aqueduct for Horatio Luro but returned to Puerto Rico. When he was first asked to ride the undefeated Camarero, Matos declined. \"He wanted to sleep in peace,\" wrote Jorge Col-n-Delgado in his book about Camarero. Assured that Coll-Vidal would not replace him if he lost aboard Camarero, Matos agreed to ride the colt.

Camarero recorded five more victories to finish his two-year-old campaign in 1953 with 18 wins. On New Year's Day in 1954, he won the 61/2-furlong Governor's Cup while carrying 120 pounds, eight more than the second-highest-weighted horse in the race. The Governor's Cup was the first leg of Puerto Rico's Triple Crown, which was established in 1951 and had not yet been won.

The next two legs were the 11/16-mile Jose de Diego Stakes and the 11/8-mile Primavera Stakes. Camarero could carry high weight, but it was unknown if he could race successfully at longer distances. On January 11, 1954, he won his 20th race by ten lengths while going 11/16 miles, eliminating any doubts of his ability.

On April 17, Camarero won the Jose de Diego Stakes for his 28th win. On May 9, carrying 15 pounds more than any other rival, he won the Primavera Stakes to become Puerto Rico's first Triple Crown winner. On his actual third birthday, Camarero won his 32nd race and set a 61/2-furlong track record. After winning another race ten days later, he earned a well-deserved rest.

Fans grew eager for Camarero's return, and on October 24, he easily won his next start. He finished his three-year-old campaign with his 37th victory on December 19 and was selected Horse of the Year.

Racing's popularity in Puerto Rico increased with each of Camarero's victories. By the end of 1954, track attendance had jumped 25%. People who had never been interested in the sport paid attention to Camarero while he chased Kincsem's record.

\"Some people would say that he was allowed to win, but that wasn't true,\" Cordero recalled. \"He used to win because he was the best. The only thing was he never raced against horses [that were not bred] in Puerto Rico. But in my opinion, he could have competed against any horse at the time. ... But since he was chasing the world record, they kept racing him against Puerto Rican-bred horses.\"

At four in 1955, Camarero won nine more races from January 6 to April 22 and was just nine wins away from the record. During the first 32 racing days of the year, total handle increased a whopping 64% compared with the previous year. Everyone in Puerto Rico was talking about Camarero and chanting \"Camarero en punta,\" or \"Camarero up front,\" a phrase used by track announcer Pito Rivera-Monge when the colt headed to victory.

Camarero kept winning. On July 18, 1955, he won his 54th race to tie Kincsem's record. The entire country waited to see when he would race again, and the interest was covered in the New York Times. Finally, it was announced that Camarero would go for the world record on August 7 in the fourth race at Quintana.

At the start of the 6 1/2-furlong race, the eight horses broke alertly. Matos held Camarero back and looked for a good spot to place him. By the half-mile pole, Matos let Camarero go, and the colt responded to win by six lengths.

\"With 600 meters to go, Camarero was already ahead and I could hear the people screaming,\" Matos recalled in Col-n-Delgado's book. \"Coming down the stretch, I knew I had the race. Camarero started to pull away easily. The closer that we would get to the finish line, the louder the people would get in the stands. It was incredible. When I passed the finish line, I remember telling myself, 'We did it. We finally did it.' \"

Fans shouted and hugged each other, while others cried. Elsewhere, the thousands of people who listened to the race on the radio began to rejoice, and many went out into the streets where drivers honked their horns. All of Puerto Rico celebrated.

\"When Camarero established the world record, I was at the track that day,\" Cordero said. \"I was too young to fully understand what was going on. All I knew was that Camarero was our champion and that every time he raced, he would win.\"Camarero was scheduled to rest following his world-record victory, but for some reason returned ten days later and scored his 56th consecutive victory.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Camarero's record of 56 consecutive wins turns 50

column1: However the win was short lived as 9 days later he would taste defeat for the first time in his career. he would go on to race 20 more times after his first defeat loosing another 3 times but managing to win another 17 more times. By the end of his career he had won 73 times out of 77 starts with two seconds and zero thirds.

Camarero would run his final race on August 26,1956 only a day later he died on August 27, 1956 of an intestinal obstruction.<ref>[https://search.proquest.com/docview/113727854 New York Times. \"Camarero, Star racer, dies.\" Aug. 28, 1956]</ref> His gravesite at Hipodromo Quintana was visited by 10,000 fans during the funeral ceremony.<ref>{{cite web

In 1958 Camarero was the first inductee in the Puerto Rico Horse Racing Hall of Fame.<ref>[http://famahipismopr.org/nativos/camarero-nativos.htm Camarero] Retrieved 2010-11-9</ref> In 2006, the name of El Nuevo Comandante racetrack in [[Canóvanas, Puerto Rico]], was changed to Hipódromo Camarero, in honor of the racehorse, as well the Camarero Awards are given annually to Puerto Rico's champion racehorses.

column1: '''George Luther Stearns''' (January 8, 1809 – April 9, 1867) was an American industrialist and [[merchant]] in [[Medford, Massachusetts]], as well as an [[abolitionist]] and a noted recruiter of black soldiers for the [[Union Army]] during the [[American Civil War]].

George L. Stearns was born in [[Medford, Massachusetts]] on January 8, 1809, the eldest son and second child of Luther and Mary (Hall) Stearns. His paternal immigrant ancestor, Isaac Sterne, arrived in Salem on June 12, 1630, from [[Suffolk]], [[England]]. He had sailed to the new colony with [[John Winthrop]], a future governor, and Sir [[Richard Saltonstall]], among others. Isaac Sterne moved to Watertown, located along the [[Charles River]], where he died in 1671. What became known as the American Stearns family (note spelling variation) grew, with branches moving northward and westward. For decades men typically worked as farmers, teachers, and clergymen.

Stearns' father, Luther Stearns, was born on February 17, 1770, the eldest of five children born to Captain Josiah Stearns, a soldier in the [[American Revolutionary War]]. He commanded a company of 50 men from [[Lunenburg, Massachusetts]]. Luther Stearns had entered Dartmouth College at age seventeen but transferred, graduating from Harvard in 1791. He worked as a tutor at Harvard and eventually studied medicine. He later became an obstetrician. He was honored in 1811 by an honorary degree from Harvard. <!-- Nice trick! Honorary degrees do not constitute certification for medical specialties -->

After getting his practice started, Luther married Mary Hall of [[Brattleboro, Vermont]], on December 29, 1799; she was 16 years old, not an uncommon marrying age for women. They settled in  Medford, Massachusetts to be closer to her relatives. They had three children together: Elizabeth Hall, George Luther, and Henry Laurens Stearns (named after the American Ambassador of that name, a distant relative). The senior Stearns later opened a private preparatory school for boys in Medford; many students came from the American South and the West Indies.

Stearns died of pneumonia on April 27, 1820, when son George was eleven years old. To earn money, young George sometimes tended the locks on the Middlesex Canal in town.  At the age of 15, he entered the workforce to support his mother and sisters.
In early life, Stearns was engaged in the business of ship-chandlery. After a prosperous career, he began the manufacture of sheet and pipe-lead, doing business in [[Boston]] and residing in Medford.

He married Mary Elizabeth Preston on October 12, 1843. They met through acquaintances, including her father Warren Preston, a probate judge in Norridgewock, Maine; and [[Lydia Maria Child]], an American abolitionist and women's rights activist.

Before voting in the Missouri and Kansas territories about the future of slavery in each jurisdiction, Stearns was one of the chief financiers of the [[Emigrant Aid Company]]. It supported the settlement of [[Kansas]] by antislavery homesteaders. He identified with the [[Abolitionism in the United States
column2: antislavery cause]], and became a [[Free Soil Party

column1: He also established the Medford station of the [[Underground Railroad]] to help escaped refugee slaves to gain freedom (some continued to Canada, which had abolished slavery). Stearns was one of the \"[[Secret Six]]\" who aided [[John Brown (abolitionist)
column2: John Brown]] in [[Kansas]], and financially supported him for the raid on [[Harpers Ferry, West Virginia
column3: Harpers Ferry]]; Brown was executed for this attack. Stearns had owned the pikes and 200 [[Sharps rifle]]s taken to  Harpers Ferry by Brown and his followers. Following Brown's arrest, Stearns briefly fled to Canada but returned to Medford to face inquiry following Brown's execution.

column1: Soon after the opening of the Civil War, Stearns advocated the enlistment of African Americans in the Union Army. Massachusetts Governor [[John Albion Andrew
column2: John Andrew]] asked Stearns to recruit the first two Northern state-sponsored black [[infantry]] [[regiment]]s. He contributed strongly to recruiting the enlistees of the [[54th Massachusetts Infantry
major]] through the recommendation of [[United States Secretary of War
column3: Secretary of War]] [[Edwin M. Stanton]]. Later he also enlisted  black soldiers for the [[United States Colored Troops
column4: U.S. Colored Troops]]US Colored Troops from [[Pennsylvania]], [[Maryland]], and [[Tennessee]]. He is credited with recruiting more than 13,000 African Americans.{{citation needed
column5: date=September 2019}} He also established schools for their children and found work for their families while the men served in the army.

column1: Stearns founded the ''Nation'', ''Commonwealth'', and ''Right Way'' newspapers for the dissemination of his ideas.<ref>James M. McPherson, ''The Struggle for Equality: Abolitionists and the Negro in the Civil War and Reconstruction'', Princeton University Press, 1964/new edition 2015</ref>

After President [[Abraham Lincoln]]'s [[Emancipation Proclamation]] in January 1863, Stearns worked tirelessly for the [[civil rights]] of African Americans. Among his many admirers and friends were [[Louisa May Alcott]], [[Henry David Thoreau]], [[Charles Sumner]], [[Frederick Douglass]], and President [[Andrew Johnson]]. He also helped to found the [[Freedmen's Bureau]], a federal organization designed to support emancipated African Americans ([[freedmen]]) in the South after the end of the war.

Stearns died of pneumonia in New York City, New York on April 9, 1867. [[Ralph Waldo Emerson]] gave the [http://www.authorama.com/cambridge-sketches-16.html eulogy] at his funeral at the [[Unitarian Universalist Church of Medford and the Osgood House
Writer [[John Greenleaf Whittier]] published a poem in honor of Stearns in the May 1867 edition of the ''[[The Atlantic
column2: Atlantic Monthly]]'', entitled \"G.L.S.\" It read, in part:<ref name=\"stearns\">{{cite book
column5: title=The Life and Public Services of George Luther Stearns

column1: Or ever our lips could ask him;
His hands the work had done.\"
\"A man who asked not to be great;
But as he served and saved the state.\"

In 1897, a monument was erected on Boston Common to commemorate Colonel [[Robert Gould Shaw]] and the 54th Massachusetts regiment he commanded. Together with 20 of his men, he was killed in July 1863 in the [[Second Battle of Fort Wagner]]. At the dedication of the monument, [[Booker T. Washington]], President of [[Tuskegee Institute]], made an address. He attributed the organization and recruiting of the US Colored Troops to be the work \"of John A. Andrew ... and that of George L. Stearns, who, with hidden generosity and a great sweet heart, helped to turn the darkest hour into day, and in doing so freely gave service, fortune and life itself to the cause which this day commemorates.\" <ref>\"Exercises at the Dedication of the Monument to Colonel Robert Gould Shaw and the Fifty-fourth Regiment of Massachusetts Infantry,\" May 31, 1897, Boston: Boston City Council, 1897.</ref>

Following this commemoration, Joseph H. Smith, a veteran of the 54th, started a movement to have a commemorative tablet placed in the Statehouse at Boston, to honor Major Stearns' services. The resolution was passed in 1897 to place a tablet in Memorial Hall or other establishments in Boston and signed by Governor Wolcott. It was not enacted at the time, but a second resolution was passed in 1901 by the Massachusetts legislature to authorize it.
The tablet is entitled: \"In Memoriam George Luther Stearns\" and says, in part:<ref name=\"Stearns\"/>
Who illustrated in his life and character
Giving his life and fortune for
The overthrow of slavery and the
To his unresting devotion and unfailing hope
And the federal government ten thousand
At a critical moment in the great war.
In the darkest hour of the republic
His faith in the ''people'' never wavered.
* Heller, Charles E., ''Portrait of an Abolitionist: A Biography of George Luther Stearns, 1809-1867.'' Greenwood Press, 1996. {{ISBN
* Heller, Charles E., \"[https://www.amazon.com/dp/0313298637 Portrait of an Abolitionist: A Biography of George Luther Stearns, 1809-1867]\"
* Renehan, Edward, ''The Secret Six: The True Tale of the Men Who Conspired With John Brown'',  1997. {{ISBN

* Stearns, Frank Preston, \"[https://archive.org/stream/publicservices00stearich/publicservices00stearich_djvu.txt ''The Life and Public Services of George Luther Stearns.'' Philadelphia, London: J. B. Lippincott Co., 1907.]\"
* Emerson, R.W., \"[http://www.authorama.com/cambridge-sketches-16.html Emerson's Tribute to George L. Stearns ]\"
* Mason, J.M., \"[http://www.wvculture.org/history/jbexhibit/masonreport.html Senate Select Committee Report on the Harper's Ferry Invasion (June 15, 1860)]\"
*[https://web.archive.org/web/20060830180227/http://www.law.umkc.edu/faculty/projects/ftrials/johnbrown/secretsixdetails.html umkc.edu website for the Secret Six]
[[Category: People of Massachusetts in the American Civil War]]

column4: U.S. Colored Troops]]US Colored Troops from [[Pennsylvania]], [[Maryland]], and [[Tennessee]]. He is credited with recruiting more than 13,000 African Americans.{{citation needed
column5: date=September 2019}} He also established schools for their children and found work for their families while the men served in the army.

column1: Stearns founded the ''Nation'', ''Commonwealth'', and ''Right Way'' newspapers for the dissemination of his ideas.<ref>James M. McPherson, ''The Struggle for Equality: Abolitionists and the Negro in the Civil War and Reconstruction'', Princeton University Press, 1964/new edition 2015</ref>

After President [[Abraham Lincoln]]'s [[Emancipation Proclamation]] in January 1863, Stearns worked tirelessly for the [[civil rights]] of African Americans. Among his many admirers and friends were [[Louisa May Alcott]], [[Henry David Thoreau]], [[Charles Sumner]], [[Frederick Douglass]], and President [[Andrew Johnson]]. He also helped to found the [[Freedmen's Bureau]], a federal organization designed to support emancipated African Americans ([[freedmen]]) in the South after the end of the war.

Stearns died of pneumonia in New York City, New York on April 9, 1867. [[Ralph Waldo Emerson]] gave the [http://www.authorama.com/cambridge-sketches-16.html eulogy] at his funeral at the [[Unitarian Universalist Church of Medford and the Osgood House
Writer [[John Greenleaf Whittier]] published a poem in honor of Stearns in the May 1867 edition of the ''[[The Atlantic
column2: Atlantic Monthly]]'', entitled \"G.L.S.\" It read, in part:<ref name=\"stearns\">{{cite book
column5: title=The Life and Public Services of George Luther Stearns

column1: Or ever our lips could ask him;
His hands the work had done.\"
\"A man who asked not to be great;
But as he served and saved the state.\"

In 1897, a monument was erected on Boston Common to commemorate Colonel [[Robert Gould Shaw]] and the 54th Massachusetts regiment he commanded. Together with 20 of his men, he was killed in July 1863 in the [[Second Battle of Fort Wagner]]. At the dedication of the monument, [[Booker T. Washington]], President of [[Tuskegee Institute]], made an address. He attributed the organization and recruiting of the US Colored Troops to be the work \"of John A. Andrew ... and that of George L. Stearns, who, with hidden generosity and a great sweet heart, helped to turn the darkest hour into day, and in doing so freely gave service, fortune and life itself to the cause which this day commemorates.\" <ref>\"Exercises at the Dedication of the Monument to Colonel Robert Gould Shaw and the Fifty-fourth Regiment of Massachusetts Infantry,\" May 31, 1897, Boston: Boston City Council, 1897.</ref>

Following this commemoration, Joseph H. Smith, a veteran of the 54th, started a movement to have a commemorative tablet placed in the Statehouse at Boston, to honor Major Stearns' services. The resolution was passed in 1897 to place a tablet in Memorial Hall or other establishments in Boston and signed by Governor Wolcott. It was not enacted at the time, but a second resolution was passed in 1901 by the Massachusetts legislature to authorize it.
The tablet is entitled: \"In Memoriam George Luther Stearns\" and says, in part:<ref name=\"Stearns\"/>
Who illustrated in his life and character
Giving his life and fortune for the
The overthrow of slavery and the
To his unresting devotion and unfailing hope
And the federal government ten thousand
At a critical moment in the great war.
In the darkest hour of the republic
His faith in the ''people'' never wavered.
